第一次世界大战标志着德国显着崛起时代的灾难性尾声。1864 年至 1871 年间，威廉一世和他的“铁腕宰相”奥托·冯·俾斯麦通过与丹麦、奥匈帝国和法国的短暂而精心策划的战争，建立了德意志帝国。统一的国家很快成为工业巨头。到 1910 年，德国拥有欧洲领先的经济体；到 1914 年，它的钢铁产量是英国的两倍，铁轨里程也是英国的两倍。从 1880 年到 1914 年，国防开支几乎翻了五倍；柏林很快就指挥了欧洲最可怕的军队，其造船厂正在建设一支可以紧追英国的海军。回头看，31自拿破仑以来就没有如果欧洲看到一个国家有这样的潜力在陆地上称霸，同时也在争夺海上霸权。

World War I marked the calamitous coda to an era of remarkable German ascent. Between 1864 and 1871, Wilhelm I and his “iron chancellor,” Otto von Bismarck, forged the German Empire through short, brilliantly orchestrated wars against Denmark, Austria-Hungary, and France. The unified state soon became an industrial juggernaut. By 1910, Germany had Europe’s leading economy; by 1914, it produced twice as much steel as Britain and had twice as many miles of railroad track. Defense spending multiplied nearly fivefold between 1880 and 1914; Berlin soon commanded Europe’s most fearsome army, and its shipyards were building a navy that would nip at Britain’s heels. Looking back, historian Paul Kennedy doubted whether the relative power “of any two neighboring states” had ever changed as much “in the course of one man’s lifetime as occurred here between Britain and Germany.”31 Not since Napoleon had Europe seen a country with such potential to dominate on land while also vying for supremacy at sea.

然而，德国的崛起始终是不稳定的，因为该国到处都是潜在的敌人。它位于拥挤的大陆中心的位置提供了巨大的影响，但也确保了其两侧国家的嫉妒。此外，德国崛起之际，世界上许多精选的殖民地财产已被不急于分享的老牌帝国宣称拥有或正在抢购。因此，即使是一个强大的、风起云涌的德国也必须小心行事，以免引发俾斯麦所说的“联盟的噩梦”——各国联合起来的敌意可能会撕裂它。32

Yet Germany’s rise was always precarious because that country had potential foes all around. Its location in the heart of a crowded continent provided tremendous influence but ensured the jealousy of states along its flanks. Germany rose, moreover, at a time when many of the world’s choice colonial possessions had been claimed or were being snapped up by established empires that were not eager to share. So even a strong, surging Germany had to tread carefully, lest it provoke what Bismarck called the “nightmare of coalitions”—the combined hostility of countries that could tear it apart.32

直到 1890 年代，德国都玩得有技巧。在统一战争期间，俾斯麦巧妙地阻止了德国的敌人联合起来对付它。1866 年普鲁士击溃奥匈帝国后，他拒绝一路进军维也纳，因为他害怕把受伤的对手变成持久的敌人；1870 年，他巧妙地挑起法国发动战争。33统一后，俾斯麦操纵了欧洲复杂的联盟政治，限制了德国的全球野心，以防止新帝国被包围。“我的非洲地图在欧洲，”他解释道：德国不应让自己成为欧洲帝国竞争的目标，而应鼓励其竞争对手向海外扩张，从而使其相互竞争。34

Until the 1890s, Germany played the game with skill. During the wars of unification, Bismarck deftly prevented Germany’s enemies from ganging up on it. He refused to march all the way to Vienna after Prussia had routed Austria-Hungary in 1866, for fear of turning a wounded rival into a lasting enemy; he cleverly provoked France into starting the war in 1870.33 After unification, Bismarck manipulated Europe’s complex alliance politics and limited Germany’s global ambitions to keep the new empire from being surrounded. “My map of Africa is here in Europe,” he explained: Rather than making itself the target of Europe’s imperial rivalries, Germany should pit its competitors against each other by encouraging them to expand abroad.34

然而，这种 19 世纪的“躲猫猫”策略并没有持续下去，因为俾斯麦本人也没有持续下去。1890 年，这位总理被更加冲动的威廉二世解雇。在威廉二世的领导下，德国在追求欧洲和全球扩张方面变得不那么拘谨了。它着手实施一项“世界政策”，旨在提供与德国竞争对手同等的市场、资源和海外帝国。它设想了一个由德国主导的中欧国家，它将提供经济安全和投射全球力量的平台。“德国人让一个邻居拥有地球，另一个邻居拥有海洋，并为自己保留天空，纯粹教条统治的时代——那些日子已经结束了，”外交部长和未来的总理伯恩哈德·冯·比洛在 1897 年宣布：德国将宣称其主权“放在阳光下。” 35

Yet this nineteenth century “hide and bide” strategy didn’t last, because Bismarck himself didn’t last. The chancellor was fired by the more impulsive Wilhelm II in 1890. Under Wilhelm II, Germany became less abashed in its pursuit of European and global aggrandizement. It embarked on a “world policy” meant to deliver markets, resources, and an overseas empire on par with those of Germany’s rivals. It envisioned a German-dominated Mitteleuropa that would provide economic security and a platform to project global power. “The days when Germans granted one neighbor the earth, the other the sea, and reserved for themselves the sky, where pure doctrine reigns—those days are over,” foreign minister and future chancellor Bernhard von Bülow announced in 1897: Germany would claim its “place in the sun.”35

该政策威胁要让其他人望尘莫及。为了在非洲、近东、太平洋和西半球获得帝国利益，德国与伦敦、巴黎、圣彼得堡和华盛顿争吵不休。德国军队的强大实力对仍然沸腾的法国构成了致命的威胁。也许最重要的是，柏林建造了一支强大的战舰“冒险舰队”，旨在将自负的皇家海军拒之门外，从而让德国在欧洲和全球范围内自由发挥。俾斯麦竭力向其他国家保证，德国将尊重现有秩序。他的继任者的行动让人怀疑柏林打算打破这一秩序——寻求“普遍的政治霸权和海上优势，威胁邻国的独立，并最终威胁到英格兰的存在，36

That policy threatened to leave others in the shade. The quest for imperial gains in Africa, the Near East, the Pacific, and the Western Hemisphere drew Germany into rows with London, Paris, St. Petersburg, and Washington. The great strength of the German army posed a mortal peril to a still-seething France. Perhaps most important, Berlin constructed a powerful “risk fleet” of battleships intended to keep the vaunted Royal Navy at bay and thereby give Germany a free hand in Europe and around the globe. Bismarck had assiduously reassured other countries that Germany would respect the existing order. The actions of his successors raised suspicions that Berlin intended to break that order—to seek “a general political hegemony and maritime ascendancy, threatening the independence of her neighbors and ultimately the existence of England,” wrote British diplomat Eyre Crowe.36

因此，德国开始促成俾斯麦所担心的包围圈。1894年，法国和俄罗斯缔结了以柏林为目标的军事同盟。英国全力维护一支无与伦比的战列舰舰队，并将其部署在德国附近。“德国将她的整个舰队始终集中在英国的几个小时内，”海军上将杰基费舍尔评论道。“因此，我们必须让一支比德国舰队强大一倍的舰队始终集中在距德国仅几小时的范围内。” 37更具破坏性的是，柏林的自信导致伦敦解决与其他竞争对手——法国、俄罗斯、日本、美国——的争端，将注意力集中在北海的威胁上。德国激活了可能将欧洲地理变成致命陷阱的焦虑情绪。用 Bülow 的话说，它面临着一个试图“孤立和瘫痪它”的“权力之环”。38

Germany thus began to precipitate the encirclement Bismarck had feared. In 1894, France and Russia concluded a military alliance aimed at Berlin. Britain threw its energies into maintaining an unmatched fleet of battleships and positioning them near Germany. “Germany keeps her whole fleet always concentrated within a few hours of England,” Admiral Jackie Fisher remarked. “We must therefore keep a fleet twice as powerful as that of Germany always concentrated within a few hours of Germany.”37 More damaging, Berlin’s assertiveness caused London to settle disputes with its other rivals—France, Russia, Japan, the United States—to focus on the menace across the North Sea. Germany had activated the anxieties that could turn Europe’s geography into a deadly trap. It faced, in Bülow’s phrasing, a “ring of Powers” who sought “to isolate and paralyze it.”38

它还面临经济遏制。德国的工业崛起自然刺激了其他地方的不安全感。1875 年的《星期六评论》警告说：“在全球的每个地方，他们都在排挤英国商人，甚至在英格兰，他们也在攫取整个分支机构，甚至是贸易中心，据为己有。” 39随着德国的行为变得更具威胁性，它的竞争对手开始征收保护性关税并开始巩固他们的帝国以应对新出现的挑战。德皇预言，英国人要“摧毁”德国工业。德国必须“建立一支强大的舰队，以防万一”。40

It also faced economic containment. Germany’s industrial rise had naturally stimulated insecurities elsewhere. “In every part of the globe they are cutting out English traders,” the Saturday Review warned in 1875, “and even in England they are seizing on whole branches and even centers of trade as their own.”39 As Germany’s conduct became more menacing, its rivals threw up protective tariffs and began consolidating their empires against the emerging challenge. The British were out to “destroy” German industry, the kaiser predicted. Germany must “forestall the evil by building a strong fleet.” 40

柏林的回应是试图打破这个圈子——通过加强它的策略。当德国在 1905 年因摩洛哥挑起与法国的帝国纠纷时，希望表明最近的英法协约是没有牙齿的，它只是表明两国多么需要彼此 - 并加速了连接巴黎的三方协约的形成，伦敦和圣彼得堡。当柏林在 1908 年至 1909 年和 1912 年至 1913 年动荡的巴尔干危机期间对俄罗斯使用胁迫威胁时，沙皇尼古拉二世政府得出结论，它必须在未来站稳脚跟。当德国于 1911 年在摩洛哥挑起另一场殖民争端时，它明确警告英国不会“不惜一切代价”寻求和平。41总理 Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg（比洛的继任者）哀叹道，这种趋势是“挑战每个人，挡住每个人的路，实际上，在这一切的过程中，没有削弱任何人。” 42一直以来，反复出现的危机使欧洲成为地缘政治温室。对战争的恐惧在四面八方升起。

Berlin’s response was to try to break the ring—through tactics that strengthened it instead. When Germany provoked an imperial imbroglio with France over Morocco in 1905, in hopes of showing that the recent Anglo-French entente was toothless, it simply demonstrated how badly the two countries needed each other—and hastened the formation of a Triple Entente linking Paris, London, and St. Petersburg. When Berlin used coercive threats against Russia during crises in the volatile Balkans in 1908–1909 and 1912–1913, Tsar Nicholas II’s government concluded that it must stand firm in the future. And when Germany stirred up another colonial dispute in Morocco in 1911, it produced explicit warnings that Britain did not seek peace “at any price.” 41 The tendency, Chancellor Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg (Bülow’s successor) lamented, was to “challenge everybody, get in everyone’s way and actually, in the course of all this, weaken nobody.” 42 All the while, recurring crises were making Europe a geopolitical hothouse. Fears of war were rising on all sides.

没有什么比德国的战争计划更能说明这种恶性循环了。为了应对对法国和俄罗斯的双线作战的威胁，总参谋部制定了施利芬计划，该计划设想对法国进行闪电打击，以便德国的部队能够然后转而阻止在东方行动缓慢的俄罗斯军队。然而，要想迅速打败法国，唯一的办法就是用刀穿过中立的比利时，绕过法德边境的坚固防御工事。这一举动很可能将英国卷入任何欧洲战争，因为伦敦不能容忍敌人在水对岸统治低地国家。这是一个荒谬的情况：德国众多的敌人产生了高风险的军事计划，这些计划很可能会产生更多。43施利芬计划还使德国对军事平衡的微小变化过于敏感，这会破坏所需的精妙时机和计划。

Nothing better illustrated this vicious circle than Germany’s war plans. To deal with the threat of a two-front fight against France and Russia, the General Staff had developed its Schlieffen Plan, which envisioned a lightning blow against France so that Germany’s forces could then pivot to block slow-mobilizing Russian armies in the East. Yet the only way to defeat France quickly was to skirt the heavy fortifications on the Franco-German frontier by knifing through neutral Belgium. That move might well bring Britain into any European war, because London could not tolerate an enemy dominating the Low Countries just across the water. It was an absurd situation: Germany’s abundance of enemies produced high-risk military plans that were liable to create even more.43 The Schlieffen Plan also made Germany hypersensitive to small shifts in the military balance, which would wreck the exquisite timing and the scheme required.

巨大的转变即将到来。1912年，俄罗斯批准扩建其波罗的海舰队；1913年开始增编47万人。在法国的财政支持下，俄罗斯也在扩大其铁路并使其现代化：它的动员时间很快就会从六周缩短到两周。法国通过了新的征兵法，通过将服役期限从两年延长到三年，威胁要抵消德国人口众多所提供的数量优势。英国宣布将由柏林建造两艘战列舰。44德国仍然是欧洲最重要的军事强国。但到了 1916 年至 1917 年，它被敌对联盟无可救药地击败了。“我相信战争是不可避免的，而且越快越好，”莫尔特克在 1912 年底宣称：现在打仗总比慢慢窒息或彻底毁灭好。45

And big shifts were coming. In 1912, Russia approved the expansion of its Baltic fleet; in 1913, it began to enlarge the army by 470,000 men. With French financial backing, Russia was also expanding and modernizing its railroads: Its mobilization time would soon fall from six weeks to two. France had passed new conscription laws that, by extending the term of service from two years to three, threatened to negate the numerical advantage that Germany’s larger population provided. The United Kingdom announced that it would build two battleships for every one by Berlin.44 Germany was still Europe’s foremost military power. But by 1916–1917, it would be hopelessly outclassed by the enemy coalition. “I believe a war to be unavoidable and: the sooner the better,” Moltke declared in late 1912: Better to fight now than suffer slow suffocation or outright destruction.45

宿命论有很多理由。德国的孤立导致它越来越依赖其主要盟友奥匈帝国。然而，这个多民族帝国正因种族紧张局势而四分五裂，并受到巴尔干地区俄罗斯支持的塞尔维亚的挑战。其他潜在盟友，如意大利和奥斯曼帝国，正在衰落。不久之后，德国可能会孤军奋战。46

There was plenty of cause for fatalism. Germany’s isolation had caused it to lean ever more heavily on its principal ally, Austria-Hungary. Yet that multinational empire was being torn apart by ethnic tensions and challenged by a Russian-backed Serbia in the Balkans. Other potential allies, such as Italy and the Ottoman Empire, were fading. Before long, Germany might be all alone.46

经济压力也在加剧。世界大战之前我，俄罗斯每年以近 10% 的速度增长，这意味着德国正在失去优势。伦敦阻止德国获得其海军在波斯所需的石油，而法国则阻止重要的铁矿石出口。德国出口商对俄罗斯将发动一场严重的关税战感到震惊。实业家瓦尔特·拉特瑙 (Walther Rathenau) 在 1913 年评论道，德国“太受世界市场的摆布了”。47它的敌人可能会扼杀德国在残酷世界中繁荣发展所需的市场和资源。

The economic pressure was also intensifying. Prior to World War I, Russia was growing at almost 10 percent annually, meaning that Germany was losing ground. London was blocking Germany from accessing the oil its navy needed in Persia, while France was obstructing crucial exports of iron ore. German exporters were petrified that Russia would launch a crippling tariff war. Germany, industrialist Walther Rathenau commented in 1913, was too much at “the mercy of the world market.” 47 Its enemies might choke off the markets and resources Germany needed to thrive in a cutthroat world.

在家里，情况也是易燃的。随着工人罢工的增加，社会主义左翼正在前进。德皇和德国军方的威信日渐式微，专制政治体制面临压力。政府激起了民族主义的热情，现在正处于令人失望的危险之中。它许诺了没有实现的胜利。即使加强镇压也无法稳定局势：德皇的助手们开始将一场短暂的胜利战争视为将民众团结在摇摇欲坠的政权背后的最后喘息方式。Bethmann-Hollweg 说，“出于内部政治原因，我需要”“宣战”。48在第一次世界大战前夕，德国是一个对未来感到恐惧的强大国家。

At home, too, conditions were flammable. The socialist Left was advancing as labor strikes multiplied. The prestige of the kaiser and the German military was ebbing, and the autocratic political system was under strain. The government had stoked nationalist passions that it was now in danger of disappointing; it had promised triumphs that were not materializing. Even increased repression could not stabilize the situation: The kaiser’s aides began to see a brief, victorious war as a last-gasp way of rallying the population behind a faltering regime. “I need” a “declaration of war for reasons of internal politics,” Bethmann-Hollweg said.48 On the eve of World War I, Germany was a mighty state that had become terrified of the future.

结果是一种现在或永远不会的心态。柏林必须尽快发动打击，以削弱法国的强国地位，让俄罗斯落后一代人，并开辟广阔的领域——从西欧延伸到乌克兰的中欧，以及遥远的新殖民地——它正在被拒绝。它必须利用其军事实力在漏洞之窗敞开之前提供的即将关闭的机会之窗。“如果我们不召唤一场战争，”一位德国外交官打趣道，“肯定没有其他人会这样做。” 49俾斯麦曾将预防性战争比作因害怕死亡而自杀。然而，这正是德国领导人现在愿意承担的风险。

The result was a now-or-never mentality. Berlin must strike soon to cripple France as a great power, set Russia back by a generation, and carve out the vast domain—a Mitteleuropa stretching from Western Europe to Ukraine, as well as new colonies far afield—it was being denied. It must exploit the closing window of opportunity that its military strength still provided before a window of vulnerability opened wide. “If we do not conjure up a war into being,” one of Germany’s diplomats quipped, “no one else certainly will do so.” 49 Bismarck had once compared preventive war to committing suicide for fear of death. Yet this was the risk German leaders were now willing to take.

机会出现在塞尔维亚激进分子暗杀弗朗茨之后1914 年 6 月 28 日，奥匈帝国王位继承人费迪南德。起初似乎不会爆发全球战争：许多欧洲领导人坚持他们的暑假计划。然而，正如后来更坦率的德国官员承认的那样，柏林在随后的危机中没有采取任何措施来阻止一场大战——却为促成一场大战做了很多事情。50

The opportunity arose after Serbian radicals assassinated Franz Ferdinand, the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, on June 28, 1914. It didn’t initially seem that a global war would erupt: Many European leaders stuck to their summer vacation plans. Yet as more candid German officials later admitted, Berlin did nothing in the subsequent crisis to prevent a major war—while doing much to precipitate one.50

时机恰到好处：德国的军事地位可能永远不会再好。危机的轮廓是有利的：愤怒的奥匈帝国肯定会与德国结盟。51这场争吵是在欧洲一个相对偏远的角落开始的，这一事实提供了一线致命的希望，伦敦最初的优柔寡断鼓舞了英国可能会袖手旁观。政治上看起来也很有希望：政府可能会通过将冲突描绘成一场针对捕食者的必要战争来激起爱国热情。于是，柏林首先向奥匈帝国开出了一张“空白支票”，推动其碾压塞尔维亚，并承诺即使与俄罗斯和法国开战也将支持它。随着危机的升级，德国政府转移了和平解决的机会，而军方不顾明显的危险准备实施施利芬计划。“这场战争将演变成一场世界大战，英国也将介入，52

The timing was right: Germany’s military position might never again be as good. The contours of the crisis were favorable: An enraged Austria-Hungary was sure to align with Germany.51 The fact that the quarrel had started in a relatively remote corner of Europe provided a fatal glimmer of hope, encouraged by London’s initial irresolution, that Great Britain might stay on the sidelines. The politics also looked promising: The government might whip up a patriotic fervor by portraying the clash as a war of necessity against predators closing in for the kill. So Berlin first issued a “blank check” to Austria-Hungary, pushing it to crush Serbia and pledging to back it even at risk of war with Russia and France. As the crisis spiraled, the German government deflected opportunities for a peaceful settlement, while the military prepared to implement the Schlieffen Plan despite the obvious dangers. “This war will turn into a world war in which England will also intervene,” Moltke acknowledged—but the alternative was for Germany to be contained and its ambitions extinguished.52

在最后一刻，德皇犹豫不决，担心会发生一场大灾难。但他最终没有破坏施利芬计划的精心安排，而是继续推进——推迟了德国动员的公开宣布，恰好足以让人觉得俄罗斯已经决定先发动战争。一名军方官员写道：“政府成功地让我们看起来像是被袭击者。” 53随之而来的不是威廉寻求的统一胜利，而是一场为期四年的混战，这场混战摧毁了他的政权，推翻了帝国，并将世界引入了工业时代的大规模屠杀。“主啊，是的，在某种意义上它是一场预防性战争，”Bethmann-Hollweg 在 1915 年承认，其动机是相信“今天的战争仍然可能不败，但两年内不可能！” 54

At the last minute, the kaiser waffled, fearful of a great catastrophe. But he ultimately pushed ahead rather than disrupt the elaborate timing of the Schlieffen Plan—delaying the public announcement of Germany’s mobilization just enough to make it appear that Russia had decided for war first. “The government has succeeded very well in making us appear as the attacked,” one military official wrote.53 What ensued was not the unifying victory Wilhelm sought, but a four-year slugfest that destroyed his regime, toppled empires, and introduced the world to industrial-age mass slaughter. “Lord yes, in a certain sense it was a preventive war,” Bethmann-Hollweg admitted in 1915, motivated by the belief that “today war is still possible without defeat, but not in two years!”54

与所有战争一样，第一次世界大战有很多原因。但从根本上说，这是一场德国的预防性战争，之所以发动是因为德皇政府认为没有其他方法可以摆脱它为自己设下的陷阱。德国是一个修正主义强国，其崛起因自身设计的反弹而受阻。因此，它押注并在一场摊牌中输掉了一切——正如莫尔特克正确预测的那样——这将“在未来几十年内毁灭几乎整个欧洲的文明”。55

World War I, like every war, had many causes. But at root it was a German preventive war, launched because the kaiser’s government saw no other way of escaping the trap it had laid for itself. Germany was a revisionist power whose rise had been stunted by the blowback from its own designs. So it wagered and lost everything on a showdown that—as Moltke rightly predicted—would “annihilate the civilization of almost the whole of Europe for decades to come.”55

“闭上眼睛跳”：日本和第二次世界大战

“CLOSE ONE’S EYES AND JUMP”: JAPAN AND WORLD WAR II

在某些情况下，经济衰退导致大国猛烈抨击而不是接受令人失望的新常态。在其他国家，扩张主义国家挑起了自己的遏制，然后孤注一掷。日本帝国在 1920 年代和 30 年代经历了这两种动态。随之而来的是第二次世界大战中可怕的太平洋战争。

In some cases, economic slumps cause major powers to lash out instead of accepting a new, disappointing normal. In others, expansionist states provoke their own containment and then go for broke. Imperial Japan experienced both dynamics in the 1920s and 1930s. What ensued was a ghastly Pacific War within World War II.

1868 年明治维新后的半个多世纪里，日本的崛起令人瞩目。现代经济和强大军事的创造，让日本在一场战争中打败了清朝，在另一场战争中击溃了沙俄，并在台湾、朝鲜和中国积累了殖民特权。第一次世界大战期间，日本夺取了德国在中国和太平洋地区的资产。然而，日本算不上是一个超级好战的流氓国家。1902年至1923年与英国结盟；它接受了美国在菲律宾的影响，以换取华盛顿支持日本控制朝鲜。从 1904 年到 1919 年，日本经济一直以 6.1% 的年增长率飞速发展。日本的出口价值在第一次世界大战期间翻了两倍。56

For more than a half-century after the Meiji Restoration in 1868, Japan was rising impressively. The creation of a modern economy and a strong military allowed Japan to defeat the Qing Dynasty in one war, rout tsarist Russia in another, and accumulate colonial privileges in Taiwan, Korea, and China. During World War I, Japan seized German holdings in China and the Pacific. Yet Japan was hardly a hyper-belligerent rogue state. It allied with Great Britain from 1902 to 1923; it accepted American influence in the Philippines in exchange for Washington blessing Japanese control of Korea. All the while, Japan’s economy was zipping along at 6.1 percent annual growth from 1904 to 1919. The value of Japanese exports tripled during World War I.56

进入 20 年代，日本看起来像是一个负责任的利益相关者。投票权扩大，政治制度变得更加民主。日本政府签署了一套被称为华盛顿体系的条约，与美国、英国和其他国家一起建立稳定的海军力量平衡，承诺尊重中国的主权和领土完整，并放弃单边扩张在亚太地区。1923 年，富兰克林·D·罗斯福评论说，美国和日本“没有一个正当理由…… . . 因为互相争斗。” 57只要全球经济对日本来说相对运转良好，它就有充分的理由不制造太多麻烦。日本外相志出原喜十郎解释说，日本需要“中国的大市场”。但如果一味奉行某些军方官员青睐的“领土扩张”，“只会破坏国际合作”。58

Into the 1920s, Japan looked like a responsible stakeholder. Voting rights expanded and the political system became more democratic. The Japanese government signed a set of treaties, known as the Washington System, in which it joined America, Britain, and other countries in creating a stable balance of naval power, pledging to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of China, and forswearing unilateral expansion in the Asia-Pacific. In 1923, Franklin D. Roosevelt commented that America and Japan “had not a single valid reason . . . for fighting each other.”57 And as long as the global economy was working relatively well for Japan, it had good reason not to cause too much trouble. Japan needed “the great market of China,” Japanese foreign minister Kijūrō Shidehara explained. But if it chased the “territorial expansion” favored by some military officials, it would “merely destroy international cooperation.”58

当繁荣结束时，麻烦就开始了。在 1920 年代，日本的年增长率下降到 1.8%。59一场大地震和银行倒闭震撼了经济。美国关税的上涨打击了日本的丝绸出口。然后大萧条来袭。市场猛然关闭，日本出口在一年内下降了 50%。60超过 260 万公民失去了工作；农民不得不卖掉他们的女儿。61共产主义和无政府主义的影响激增。“失业人数每天都在增加。这个家庭正在破裂。饿死的人满街都是，”一位政府官员写道。62最重要的是，全球转向保护主义使日本对一体化的追求显得不切实际——并使对扩张和自给自足的追求更具吸引力。“世界上的经济战，”未来的外务大臣松冈洋介观察到，“正在形成更大的经济集团。” “窒息”的日本需要“让我们呼吸的空间”。63

The trouble began when the prosperity ended. Japanese growth dropped to 1.8 percent annually during the 1920s.59 A major earthquake and a banking collapse rocked the economy. Rising American tariffs battered Japanese silk exports. Then the Great Depression struck. Markets slammed shut and Japanese exports fell by 50 percent in a single year.60 More than 2.6 million citizens lost their jobs; farmers resorted to selling their daughters.61 Communist and anarchist influences proliferated. “Unemployment is increasing daily. The family is breaking up. Starving people fill the streets,” one government official wrote.62 Above all, the global turn to protectionism made Japan’s pursuit of integration seem quixotic—and made a quest for expansion and autarky more attractive. “The economic warfare in the world,” future foreign minister Yosuke Matsuoka observed, “is tending to create larger economic blocs.” A “suffocated” Japan needed “room that will let us breathe.”63

萧条使日本对经济的变化特别敏感中国。在 20 年代后期，蒋介石领导下的民族主义运动开始攻击日本的经济特权并争夺其影响力。蒋介石的苏军正在行军。与此同时，其他竞争对手也在潜伏：苏联派出 100,000 名士兵重新夺回被满洲军阀占领的重要铁路，然后达成一项协议，允许他们的货物（而不是日本的）免税通过该地区。64日本 80% 的海外商业投资都在中国。东京 40% 的贸易和关键资源（如煤炭、铁和谷物）依赖满洲。65该地区是抵御外国入侵的重要缓冲地带。随着日本停滞不前，其他大国似乎做好了出击的准备。

The depression made Japan especially sensitive to changes in China. During the late 1920s, a nationalist movement under Chiang Kai-shek had begun attacking Japan’s economic privileges and contesting its influence. Chiang’s Soviet-trained army was on the march. Other rivals were, simultaneously, prowling: The Soviets sent 100,000 troops to retake a crucial railway that had been seized by a Manchurian warlord, then secured an agreement that allowed their goods, but not Japan’s, to pass through the region duty-free.64 Eighty percent of Japan’s overseas business investment was in China. Tokyo relied on Manchuria for 40 percent of its trade and critical resources such as coal, iron, and grain.65 The region was a crucial buffer against foreign encroachment. As Japan stagnated, other powers seemed primed to pounce.

东京的回答是国内的法西斯主义和国外的暴力。从 20 年代后期开始，军方发动了一场缓慢的政变，而极端民族主义的狂热分子则谋杀了总理和其他被认为不够爱国的官员。政府禁止异议，关押批评者，并建立了一个无处不在的警察国家。它对银行和工业施加了更大的控制，以利用国家的资源进行竞争。一个方兴未艾的军事派系鼓吹“全面战争”的必要性，并开始动员社会应对冲突。66一位西方观察家写道，到 1941 年，日本已经“在通向极权主义国家的道路上走了很长一段路”。67

Tokyo’s answer was fascism at home and violence abroad. From the late 1920s onward, the military conducted a slow-motion coup, while ultranationalist zealots murdered prime ministers and other officials deemed insufficiently patriotic. The government outlawed dissent, jailed its critics, and built a pervasive police state. It exerted greater control over banks and industries to harness the nation’s resources for rivalry. An ascendant military faction preached the need for “total war” and began mobilizing society for conflict.66 By 1941, one Western observer wrote, Japan had walked “a long way on the road to totalitarian statehood.” 67

它也成为了一个连环侵略者。1931 年，军队夺取了满洲的控制权，使其成为日本的傀儡国。1932 年至 1933 年，日军进一步向中国沿海推进并深入内陆。1934 年，东京宣布东亚为它的专属领地——美国大使约瑟夫·格鲁 (Joseph Grew) 写道，这是一种反门罗主义，“将中国置于日本的监护状态”。68退出华盛顿条约后，日本还开始了大规模的军事建设，包括航空母舰、巨型战列舰和最先进的战斗机。到 1936 年，日本官员制定了计划一个庞大的亚洲帝国，通过赋予日本丰富的资源、市场和地缘政治空间，使日本成为超级大国。

It had also become a serial aggressor. The army seized control of Manchuria in 1931, making it a Japanese puppet state. In 1932–1933, Japanese troops pushed farther down China’s coast and into its interior. In 1934, Tokyo declared East Asia its exclusive domain—a reverse Monroe Doctrine that, U.S. ambassador Joseph Grew wrote, “places China in a state of tutelage under Japan.” 68 Withdrawing from the Washington treaties, Japan also began a massive military buildup featuring aircraft carriers, monster battleships, and state-of-the-art fighter planes. And by 1936, Japanese officials had drawn up plans for a vast Asian empire that would make Japan a superpower by giving it copious resources, markets, and geopolitical space.

根据这个计划，满洲将得到发展，中国的大片土地将被夺取。日本将攫取欧洲在东南亚的殖民地，这些殖民地富含石油、橡胶和其他资源；它将宣称拥有整个西太平洋和中太平洋的战略岛屿。所有这一切都需要准备与肯定会抵抗日本对如此大而重要的地区的统治的国家——苏联、英国和美国——开战。69除非日本得到它所要求的，否则日本首相近卫文麿早前写道，它必须“为了自我保护而破坏现状”。70

Under this plan, Manchuria would be developed and large swaths of China would be seized. Japan would grab European colonies in Southeast Asia that were rich in oil, rubber, and other resources; it would claim strategic islands throughout the western and central Pacific. All of this would require preparations for war with the countries that would surely resist Japanese dominance of such a large, vital region—the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and America.69 Unless Japan got what it demanded, Japanese prime minister Fumimaro Konoye had earlier written, it must “destroy the status quo for the sake of self-preservation.”70

Konoye 是一个守信的人。1937年，日本在中国发动了一场大规模、残酷的战争，动用了多达80万的军队来迫使蒋介石就范。1938年，近卫宣布建立“新秩序”，即日本主导的亚洲，条条大路通东京。Konoye 政府将国家置于战争状态以支持这个扩张的帝国计划，同时与其他法西斯列强——纳粹德国和意大利——结盟以寻求建立自己的帝国。“民主时代结束了，”松冈宣称。“极权主义。. . 将控制世界。” 71

Konoye was a man of his word. In 1937, Japan launched a massive, brutal war in China, using up to 800,000 troops in a bid to force Chiang into submission. In 1938, Konoye announced the creation of the “New Order,” a Japanese-dominated Asia in which all roads led to Tokyo. Konoye’s government put the country on a war footing to support this expanding imperial project, while allying with other fascist powers—Nazi Germany and Italy—seeking empires of their own. “The era of democracy is finished,” Matsuoka declared. “Totalitarianism . . . will control the world.”71

然而大片大片的战火却变成了泥潭：早在珍珠港事件之前，日军就已经付出了60万人伤亡的血代价。72它迫使动荡不安的民众面临食物短缺和其他牺牲。反常的是，扩张也让东京更加依赖其潜在敌人的资源来维持战争机器的运转。二战前，日本“80% 的石油、90% 的汽油、74% 的废铁和 60% 的机床”都是从美国进口的。73 “我们的目标是结束 70 年来在商业和经济上对英国和美国的依赖，”军方官员曾发誓——但中国一场无休止的战争产生了相反的效果。74

Yet war in the expanses of China turned into a quagmire: Even before Pearl Harbor, Japanese forces had paid a blood price of 600,000 casualties.72 It forced food shortages and other sacrifices on a restive population. Perversely, expansion also left Tokyo more reliant on its potential enemies for resources to keep the war machine humming. Before World War II, Japan “imported 80 percent of its oil, 90 percent of its gasoline, 74 percent of its scrap iron, and 60 percent of its machine tools” from America.73 “We are aiming to put an end to seventy years’ dependence on Britain and America commercially and economically,” army officials had vowed—but an interminable war in China had the opposite effect.74

同时把矛头指向了日本。向满洲和中国北部的推进最终引发了与苏联的一场短暂但惩罚性的战争，斯大林的红军在这场战争中重创了日本的第六集团军。日本对中国的毒辣和对东南亚的虎视眈眈，疏远了英国等欧洲列强。尽管美国对征服满洲做出了微弱的反应，但日本谋求地区主导地位的胆大妄为和中国战争的恐怖——恐怖爆炸、蓄意屠杀和强奸平民、使用生物武器——开始引起人们的注意。与华盛顿为敌。75

It simultaneously put a target on Japan’s back. The push into Manchuria and northern China eventually incited a brief but punishing war with the Soviet Union, in which Stalin’s Red Army pounded Japan’s Sixth Army. Japan’s viciousness in China and covetous gaze toward Southeast Asia alienated the United Kingdom and other European powers. And while America had reacted weakly to the conquest of Manchuria, the audacity of Japan’s drive for regional dominance and the sheer horror of the war in China—the terror bombing, the deliberate massacre and rape of civilians, the use of biological weapons—began to make Washington an enemy.75

“当前的恐怖统治和国际无法无天状态，”罗斯福宣称，威胁着“文明的根基”。76到 1940 年，美国在财政上支持蒋政府并限制向日本出口航空材料、高辛烷值汽油、废金属和其他商品。美国还通过使自己成为军事超级大国来应对欧洲和亚洲的威胁。那一年，美国海军订购了9艘战列舰、11艘航空母舰、8艘重巡洋舰、31艘轻巡洋舰和181艘驱逐舰。FDR 设定了每年生产 50,000 架飞机的目标；国会将美国陆军的授权人力增加了近 100 万人。771940 年 9 月，日本与意大利和德国签署了三方条约，同时还占领了法属印度支那北部，美国官员得出结论认为，东京已经与正在毁灭世界的邪恶歹徒为伍。

“The present reign of terror and international lawlessness,” FDR declared, threatened “the very foundations of civilization.”76 By 1940, the United States was floating Chiang’s government financially and constricting the export of aviation materials, high-octane gasoline, scrap metal, and other goods to Japan. America was also responding to threats in Europe and Asia by making itself a military superpower. That year, the U.S. Navy placed orders for 9 battleships, 11 aircraft carriers, 8 heavy cruisers, 31 light cruisers, and 181 destroyers. FDR set a target of producing 50,000 airplanes per year; Congress raised the authorized manpower of the U.S. Army by nearly 1 million men.77 And when Japan signed the Tripartite Pact with Italy and Germany, while also occupying northern French Indochina in September 1940, U.S. officials concluded that Tokyo had cast its lot with vile gangsters who were destroying the world.

至此，日本脖子上的战略套索正在收紧。鉴于“全面战争”集团，日本不得不继续推进——尤其是在印度支那和荷属东印度群岛——建立其自给自足的帝国。然而这样做意味着走向与英国的战争美国，一个经济规模是日本十二倍的国家。78美国可以通过关闭为其陆军和海军提供燃料的石油运输来扼杀日本；美国可以调动无与伦比的军事力量。“任何看过底特律汽车工厂和得克萨斯州油田的人都知道，日本缺乏与美国进行海军竞赛的国力，”山本五十六海军上将警告说。79就像威廉的德国一样，日本已经走投无路：扩张导致了孤立，只能通过羞辱性的撤退——从中国撤出并放弃新秩序——或者把一切赌注押在狂野的胜利上来克服。

By this point, a strategic noose was tightening around Japan’s neck. In view of the “total war” clique, Japan had to keep pushing—especially into Indochina and the Dutch East Indies—to build its autarkic empire. Yet doing so meant marching toward war with Britain and with America, a country whose economy was twelve times the size of Japan’s.78 The United States could throttle Japan by turning off the oil shipments that fueled its army and navy; America could mobilize unmatchable military power. “Anyone who has seen the auto factories in Detroit and the oil fields in Texas knows that Japan lacks the national power for a naval race with America,” Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto warned.79 Like Wilhelm’s Germany, Japan had cornered itself: Expansion had led to isolation that could only be overcome by a humiliating retreat—withdrawal from China and abandonment of the New Order—or by staking everything on a wild dash for victory.

使全家下注的选择更具吸引力的是，日本在 1940 年末和 1941 年的军事机会窗口很小。德国在西欧的闪电战打垮了法国，让英国为生存而战，在东南亚创造了“百年机遇”。80罗斯福因与希特勒争夺大西洋控制权的未宣战而分心。日本于 1941 年 4 月与苏联签订互不侵犯条约，随后希特勒于 6 月入侵该国，暂时消除了来自北方的任何威胁。尤其重要的是，由于早期的重新武装，日本仍然在军事上处于领先地位：它拥有 10 艘航空母舰，而英美军队在整个太平洋地区拥有的航空母舰只有 3 艘。81问题是窗口将保持打开多长时间。

What made the bet-the-house option more appealing was that Japan had, in late 1940 and 1941, a narrow window of military opportunity. Germany’s blitzkrieg in Western Europe had broken France and left Britain fighting for its life, creating “the opportunity of a century” in Southeast Asia.80 FDR was distracted by the undeclared battle with Hitler for control of the Atlantic. Japan’s nonaggression pact with the Soviet Union in April 1941, followed by Hitler’s invasion of the country in June, temporarily neutralized any threat from the north. Not least, Japan still had a military lead thanks to its early rearmament: It possessed ten aircraft carriers to the three that Anglo-American forces had across the entire Pacific.81 The question was how long the window would stay open.

答案在 1941 年下半年出现。在日本军队进入印度支那南部后，罗斯福实施了全面的石油禁运，这可能会使日本的船只和飞机冒烟。日本领导人认为，日本“就像池塘里的一条鱼，水正在逐渐流失”。82美国正在用 B-17 轰炸机和 P-40 战斗机加强其在菲律宾的防御。军方与英荷会谈，配合经济制裁，让日本害怕被包围快完成了。随着美国加速重整军备，到 1942 年至 1943 年，美国海军将拥有“日本的四倍吨位和四倍的空中力量”。83到那时，日本称霸亚洲就无望了。它的领导人将名誉扫地：这个国家流过的所有鲜血，忍受过的所有苦难，都将化为乌有。日本领导人总结道，美国将“要求越来越多的让步，最终我们的帝国将屈服于美国的脚下。” 84

The answer came in the second half of 1941. After Japanese forces moved into southern Indochina, FDR imposed a full oil embargo that threatened to leave Japan’s ships and planes running on fumes. Japan was “like a fish in a pond from which the water was gradually being drained away,” its leaders believed.82 America was bulking up its defenses in the Philippines with B-17 bombers and P-40 fighters. Military staff talks with the British and Dutch, and economic sanctions coordinated with them, made the Japanese fear that their encirclement was nearly complete. And with American rearmament accelerating, the U.S. Navy would, by 1942–1943, have “four times the tonnage and four times the air power of Japan’s.”83 At that point, Japan would have no hope of hegemony in Asia. Its leaders would be totally discredited: All the blood the nation had shed, all the privations it had endured, would be for naught. America would “demand more and more concessions,” Japanese leaders concluded, “and ultimately our empire will lie prostrate at the feet of the United States.”84

1941 年秋天，日本政府决定夺取荷属东印度群岛、菲律宾以及从新加坡到太平洋中部的其他领土，尽管这意味着要与英国和美国开战。几乎没有日本官员相信该国能够赢得全面斗争。“我们可以给你一场为期六个月到一年的疯狂表演，但如果战争拖到两三年，我对结果就没把握了，”山本预测道。85但他们担心另一种选择是急剧下降，使日本在敌人面前无能为力。他们希望一连串的雷击能够让美国士气低落，以至于它可能会求和而不是继续战斗。充其量，战争会带来可怕的风险；在最坏的情况下，它可能会导致国家毁灭。但有时，最终将日本带入战争的东条英机将军说，“一个人必须鼓起足够的勇气，闭上眼睛，跳下去。” 86

In the fall of 1941, the Japanese government decided to seize the Dutch East Indies, Philippines, and other possessions from Singapore to the central Pacific, even though this meant war with Britain and America. Few Japanese officials believed that the country could win an all-out struggle. “We can give you a wild show for six months to a year, but if the war drags on to two and three years, I cannot be confident of the outcome,” Yamamoto predicted.85 But they feared that the alternative was a sharp decline that would leave Japan impotent before its enemies. And they hoped that a series of lightning blows could so demoralize the United States that it might sue for peace rather than continue the fight. At best, war would bring terrible risks; at worst, it might cause national destruction. But sometimes, said Hideki Tojo, the general who ultimately led Japan into war, “one must conjure up enough courage, close one’s eyes, and jump.”86

这就是突然袭击珍珠港的起源。如果战争不可避免，那么为什么不通过摧毁美国太平洋舰队来换取更多暂时的军事优势——以及更多时间来消化日本的新征服成果？具有讽刺意味的是，这次袭击是如此具有破坏性，而且在美国人眼中如此危险，以至于它激励该国不惜一切代价摧毁日本。“日本人，”一位国会议员怒吼道，“已经面目全非，发疯了，他们无缘无故的攻击导致了军队、海军和国家的自杀。” 87

This was the genesis of the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor. If war was inevitable, then why not buy more temporary military advantage—and more time to digest Japan’s new conquests—by devastating the U.S. Pacific Fleet? The irony was that the attack was so devastating and, in American eyes, so treacherous, that it galvanized the country to destroy Japan whatever the cost. “The Japanese,” one congressman thundered, “have gone stark, raving mad, and have, by their unprovoked attack committed military, naval, and national suicide.”87

第二次世界大战对日本来说几乎是自杀。然而，原因不是精神错乱，而是一个修正主义梦想即将破灭的国家的绝望。十年来，日本一直处于激进的撕裂状态。当它意识到时间不多时，它变得最危险。

World War II would prove nearly suicidal for Japan. The cause, however, was not insanity but the desperation of a country whose revisionist dreams were about to be shattered. Japan had been on an aggressive tear for a decade. It became most dangerous when it realized that time was running out.

历史学家通常将第一次世界大战前的德国和二战前的日本视为崛起中的国家。1868年以后的几十年里，日本由弱变强；它的帝国在 1930 年代迅速发展。德国在 1914 年是一个比 1871 年更强大的竞争者。这两个国家的崛起都足够远、足够快，足以从根本上挑战全球现状。

Historians typically think of pre–World War I Germany and pre–World War II Japan as rising countries. Japan had gone from weakness to strength in the decades after 1868; its empire grew rapidly in the 1930s. Germany was a vastly more formidable contender in 1914 than it had been in 1871. Both countries had risen far enough, fast enough to fundamentally challenge the global status quo.

然而在高潮时刻，德意志帝国和日本帝国的领导人并不觉得自己在上升。停滞、包围或某种组合使他们相信他们的时机正在溜走。一个开始担心未来的修正主义力量可能会比一个认为明天会比今天更好的力量更加冲动。这才是我们应该担心的真正陷阱——一个有抱负的超级大国在其中达到顶峰然后拒绝承担下降的痛苦后果的陷阱。

Yet at the climactic moment, imperial German and imperial Japanese leaders did not feel like they were moving up. Stagnation, encirclement, or some combination convinced them that their moment was slipping away. A revisionist power that has begun to fear the future may well act more impulsively than one that thinks tomorrow will be better than today. That’s the real trap we ought to worry about—the trap in which an aspiring superpower peaks and then refuses to bear the painful consequences of descent.

听到中共与德意志帝国相提并论，中国当今的领导人会感到愤怒，更不用说日本帝国了。平心而论，中国没有像日本在第二次世界大战前十年实施的军事侵略那样进行军事侵略。

China’s present-day leaders would be outraged to hear the CCP compared to imperial Germany, let alone to imperial Japan. In fairness, China hasn’t embarked on anything like the military aggression that Japan perpetrated for a decade prior to World War II.

但不要太过安慰。德意志帝国在 1871 年之后的四十年里没有发动过一场大战，但在 1914 年却把世界推向了一场规模几乎难以想象的灾难。第一次世界大战是“洪水”。. . 一场自然的痉挛，”英国的戴维·劳合·乔治说，“一场地震正在撼动欧洲生活的基石。” 88当修正主义势力看到墙，事情会很快变得丑陋——其后果在不久前似乎是不可想象的。

But don’t take too much comfort. Imperial Germany didn’t wage a major war for four decades after 1871, yet in 1914 it did much to thrust the world into a catastrophe on an almost unimaginable scale. World War I was “the deluge . . . a convulsion of nature,” said Britain’s David Lloyd George, “an earthquake which is upheaving the very rocks of European life.”88 When revisionist powers see the writing on the wall, things can get ugly quickly—with consequences that might have seemed inconceivable not long before.

这是另一个令人担忧的原因：与日本一样，中国勾选了很多令人担忧的方框。它正在应对极难摆脱的长期经济放缓。它遇到了一大批竞争对手，这些竞争对手虽然是渐进式的，但正在努力阻碍北京的前进。中国也有威权体制和经济模式，使重商主义扩张更具吸引力。其贸易预期正在变得非常负面。事实上，中国已经在进行实践——军事建设、寻找势力范围、努力控制关键技术和资源——我们期望处于其地位的国家能够做到。如果说一个已经显着崛起但现在正努力应对停滞和包围的国家有侵略的秘诀，那么中国拥有所有关键成分。

Here’s another reason for concern: Like Japan, China checks a lot of worrying boxes. It is dealing with a prolonged economic slowdown that will be extremely difficult to escape. It is encountering a ring of rivals that are working, albeit incrementally, to stymie Beijing’s advance. China also has an authoritarian system and an economic model that make mercantilist expansion more attractive. Its trade expectations are turning starkly negative. Indeed, China is already engaging in the practices—the military buildup, the search for spheres of influence, the effort to control critical technologies and resources—we would expect from a state in its position. If there is a recipe for aggression by a country that has risen remarkably but is now struggling to deal with stagnation and encirclement, China has all the critical ingredients. So let’s now look closely at what moves a more combative China might make.

5个

5

风暴聚集

The Gathering Storm

中国轰6K轰炸机从大陆机场起飞，两架先进战斗机护航。它向东飞行，在台湾和菲律宾之间，前往开阔的太平洋。当它进入目标射程时，它发射了一枚精确制导导弹，飞入关岛的安德森空军基地，引发大规模爆炸，并摧毁了美国在西太平洋的空中力量中心。这次袭击是人们长期担心的中美战争的毁灭性齐射。

The Chinese H-6K bomber took off from an airfield on the mainland, with two advanced fighter jets as escorts. It flew east, between Taiwan and the Philippines, en route to the open Pacific. When it came within range of its target, it released a precision-guided missile that ripped into Andersen Air Force Base on Guam, triggering massive explosions and ravaging the central hub for U.S. airpower in the western Pacific. The attack was a devastating salvo in the long-feared Sino-American war.

幸运的是，该事件只是中国人民解放军空军 (PLAAF) 于 2020 年 9 月发布的视频模拟，以展示其不断提高的技能和能力。按照中国知识产权盗窃的最佳传统，中国空军甚至拼接了好莱坞电影《变形金刚》和《巨石强森》中的镜头。但这段视频——称之为“战狼电影摄影”——只是对中国战略可怕转变的最新警告。

Fortunately, the incident was only a video simulation, released by the People’s Liberation Army Air Force (PLAAF) in September 2020 to show off its improving skills and capabilities. In the best tradition of Chinese intellectual property theft, the PLAAF even spliced in footage from the Hollywood films Transformers and The Rock. But the video—call it “Wolf-Warrior cinematography”—was just the latest warning about a scary shift in Chinese strategy.

未来的历史学家会说我们早该预见到它的到来。自 2012 年上台以来，习近平一直在暗示中国转向黑暗面。他关于国家安全的内部讲话已经一贯强调两个主题：一是中国面临日益恶化的威胁。其次，中共必须先发制人地粉碎这些威胁，以免它们破坏其统治并破坏其未来的宏伟计划。习近平担心的主要威胁是我们所描述的那些——增长放缓和外国敌意——他所提倡的反应类似于过去的峰值大国的反应：重商主义、镇压和复仇主义的激增。

Future historians will say we should have seen it coming. Xi Jinping has been telegraphing a Chinese turn to the dark side since he took power in 2012. His internal speeches on national security have consistently stressed two themes: First, China faces worsening threats. Second, the CCP must preemptively crush those threats before they destroy its rule and derail its grand plans for the future. The primary threats Xi worries about are the ones we’ve described—slowing growth and foreign hostility—and the response he advocates resembles that of past peaking powers: a surge of mercantilism, repression, and revanchism.

这会是什么样子？中国可能不会疯狂地在所有战线上扩张，也不会对其人口实施朝鲜式的封锁。习近平和他的亲信太聪明了。他们知道当德国和日本试图抢占欧亚大陆时会发生什么，他们也看到了死板的极权主义和自给自足是如何毁掉苏联的。但中国领导人也知道，向增长乏力和战略包围的“新常态”屈服会使他们面临外国掠夺和国内动荡。因此，中共将进行有计划的胁迫和扩张，以阻止对手并确保中国梦。习近平已经开始实施这一战略的关键要素——这可不是什么美好的景象。

What will this look like? China probably won’t expand on all fronts in a mad frenzy or impose North Korea–style lockdowns on its population. Xi and his cronies are too smart for that. They know what happened when Germany and Japan tried to run the table in Eurasia, and they saw how rigid totalitarianism and autarky doomed the Soviet Union. But China’s leaders also know that surrendering to a “new normal” of sluggish growth and strategic encirclement would expose them to foreign predation and domestic unrest. So the CCP will engage in calculated coercion and expansion to keep rivals at bay and secure the Chinese dream. Xi has already started to implement key elements of this strategy—and it’s not a pretty sight.

首先，中国将加倍努力打造横跨欧亚大陆和非洲的经济帝国。面对国内产能过剩和日益抬头的外国保护主义，中国正在加紧开展大规模运动，开辟专属经济区，其企业将在这些区域享有进入市场和原材料的特权。与此同时，中国正在竞相宣称技术至上，并在全球范围内传播其数字影响力。用习近平的话说，这些努力是为了让中国“立于不败之地”——让北京有能力称霸敌人和附庸。1总的来说，中国的行动有可能使全球经济分裂并引发新的冷战。

For starters, China will redouble its efforts to forge an economic empire across Eurasia and Africa. Awash in excess production capacity at home and confronted by rising foreign protectionism, China is intensifying a massive campaign to carve out exclusive economic zones where its firms will enjoy privileged access to markets and raw materials. At the same time, China is racing to claim technological primacy and spread its digital influence around the world. These efforts are meant, in Xi’s words, to make China “invincible”—to give Beijing leverage to lord over enemies and vassals.1 Collectively, China’s actions threaten to balkanize the global economy and fuel a new Cold War.

一个不安全的中国也将更加热衷于后退边境的自由。中共不会输出特定的“中国模式”，但它会试图通过改变专制与民主之间的全球平衡来保护其政权。北京正迅速成为一支强大的反民主力量，配备了比毛泽东想象的更先进的监视和惩罚工具。在民主世界正遭受自 1930 年代以来最大的危机之际，它正在努力支持独裁者并破坏自由社会的稳定。

An insecure China will also more zealously roll back the frontiers of freedom. The CCP won’t export a specific “China model,” but it will try to protect its regime by shifting the global balance between autocracy and democracy. Beijing is quickly becoming a potent anti-democratic force, armed with more advanced tools of surveillance and punishment than Mao Zedong ever could have imagined. And it is working hard to prop up dictators and destabilize liberal societies just as the democratic world is suffering its greatest crisis since the 1930s.

最后，中国正在为战争做准备。它正在进行的军事建设不同于二战以来的任何一次。尽管中国的邻国和美国迟迟没有加强他们的军队，但他们的许多新武器系统在多年内都不会投入使用。与此同时，中国将有机会夺取东亚有争议的领土，并沿着其海上侧翼突破美国的联盟链。

Finally, China is gearing up for war. Its ongoing military buildup is unlike any since World War II. Although China’s neighbors and the United States are belatedly beefing up their militaries, many of their new weapons systems won’t be operational for years. In the meantime, China will have a chance to seize contested territory in East Asia and blast through the chain of U.S. alliances along its maritime flank.

在这些领域中的每一个领域，中国都试图在它们关闭之前冲过近期的机会之窗，并在打开的长期漏洞之窗中冲刺。在这样做的过程中，中国正在走一条熟悉的野心、绝望和侵略的道路。一个崛起的中国能够容忍一些异议，放弃一些扩张的机会，并缓和危机——相信它的财富、权力和地位正在上升——一个达到顶峰的中国将更加渴望在地缘政治上取得胜利，并做好反应过度的准备轻视和挫折。经过数十年的军事建设和强大的经济影响工具的开发，中国现在看起来已经准备好在有机会的时候利用这些能力。结果对世界来说可能是灾难性的。

In each of these areas, China is trying to sprint through near-term windows of opportunity before they close and longer-term windows of vulnerability open. In so doing, China is walking a familiar path of ambition, desperation, and aggression. Whereas a rising China could afford to tolerate some dissent, forgo some opportunities for expansion, and de-escalate crises—confident that its wealth, power, and status were rising—a peaking China will be more desperate to score geopolitical wins and primed to overreact to slights and setbacks. Having spent decades building up its military and developing powerful tools of economic influence, China now looks ready to cash in on those capabilities while it has the chance. The results could be disastrous for the world.

中国一触即发的安全战略

CHINA’S HAIR-TRIGGER SECURITY STRATEGY

2014年，中国首次制定了正式的国家安全战略，并成立了新的国家安全委员会进行统筹。2 Xi 对原因毫不怀疑。他在一系列演讲中说中国面临“历史上最复杂的内外因素” 3，“面临越来越多的威胁和挑战”。4为强调危险，习近平引用了战国时期（公元前 500 年至公元前 200 年）的经典著作《易经》，其中中国陷入自相残杀：存世之时，安世之乱。” 5个

In 2014, China produced a formal national security strategy for the first time and established a new National Security Commission to orchestrate it.2 Xi left no doubt about why. In a series of speeches, he said that China faced “the most complicated internal and external factors in its history”3 and “confronted increasing threats and challenges.” 4 To underscore the peril, Xi quoted from the Book of Changes, a classic text from the Warring States period (500–200 BC) in which China collapsed into internecine strife: “One should be mindful of possible danger in times of peace, downfall in times of survival, and chaos in times of stability.”5

外国观察家可能会将习近平的警告视为偏执狂或为强人统治辩护的策略。但中国领导人几年前就预见到这一黑暗时期的到来。2002 年，时任国家主席江泽民创造的官方口号是，中国将享受以和平的国际关系和稳定的经济发展为标志的两个十年“战略机遇期”。现在二十年过去了，中共的新口号是中国正在见证“百年未有之大变局”，这个口号既蕴含着诱人的机遇，也蕴含着严峻的威胁。6个一个世纪前，随着旧帝国的崩溃和新兴大国的出现，全球平衡正在发生变化。然而，这些崛起的大国最终在一场全球战争中被摧毁。此外，中国在 1920 年代的部分时间里陷入了所谓的军阀时代——一个听起来很糟糕的时期——在外国列强和受过西方教育的中国革命者推翻清朝之后爆发。

Foreign observers might dismiss Xi’s warning as paranoia or a ploy to justify strongman rule. But China’s leaders saw this dark period coming years ago. In 2002, the official mantra, coined by then-president Jiang Zemin, was that China would enjoy a two-decade “period of strategic opportunity” marked by peaceful international relations and steady economic development. Now those twenty years are up, and the CCP’s new catchphrase is that China is witnessing “profound changes unseen in 100 years,” a slogan that connotes both tantalizing opportunity and grave threats.6 A century ago, the global balance was in flux, as old empires crumbled and rising powers emerged. Yet those rising powers were eventually destroyed in a global war. Moreover, China spent part of the 1920s mired in its so-called Warlord Era—a period every bit as bad as it sounds—which erupted after foreign powers and Western-educated Chinese revolutionaries brought down the Qing Dynasty.

今天，中共领导人知道他们的国家再次面临增长放缓和外国包围的大问题。中国新的国家安全战略旨在通过两种方式应对这些威胁。

Today, CCP leaders know that their nation again faces big problems, in the form of slowing growth and foreign encirclement. China’s new national security strategy is designed to address those threats in two ways.

一是“把安全融入国家发展的每一个领域、每一个进程”。7尽管政权安全曾经是许多政府优先事项之一（尽管是最重要的），但现在它是优先事项。8所有其他问题——经济发展、技术创新、环境政策——是保持党执政的主要方针的附属物。因此，每一个问题都是国家安全的问题。贸易战不再只是经济分歧；这是对中国综合国力的冲击，可能是一场枪战的前奏。这种政策制定的安全化是危险的，因为它将每一个问题都提升到了至关重要的国家利益的高度，并为极端反应提供了正当理由。例如，如果一个竞争大国试图伤害中国经济，所有的选择都摆在桌面上，包括军事报复。

First, the strategy “integrates security into every domain and every process of national development.”7 Whereas regime security used to be one of many government priorities (albeit the most important), now it is the priority.8 All other issues—economic development, technological innovation, environmental policy—are adjuncts to the prime directive of keeping the party in power. As a result, every issue is a matter of national security. A trade war is no longer just an economic disagreement; it is an assault on China’s comprehensive national power and a possible prelude to a shooting war. This securitization of policy making is dangerous, because it elevates every concern to the level of a vital national interest and justifies extreme responses. If a competing power tries to hurt China’s economy, for example, all options are on the table, including military retaliation.

其次，中国的战略包括预防性解决方案。鉴于前几届中国政府信奉“维稳”原则，新政策的重点是在威胁转移之前“预防和控制”威胁。中国文件将国家安全威胁比作需要在扩散到国家重要器官之前迅速切除的癌性肿瘤。相互竞争的意识形态，例如自由主义和伊斯兰主义，是中国人民必须免疫的传染病。正如 Sheena Chestnut Greitens 所表明的那样，这些医学隐喻证明了在人们表现出威胁症状之前很久就瞄准和“治疗”他们是合理的。9最明显的例子是在新疆，中国在那里将超过 100 万维吾尔人法外关押在集中营中。10但中国也在外交事务中运用预防逻辑，其方式与以往处于巅峰状态的大国会很熟悉。

Second, China’s strategy embraces preventive solutions. Whereas previous Chinese administrations espoused a doctrine of “stability maintenance,” the new policy focuses on “preventing and controlling” threats before they metastasize. Chinese documents compare national security threats to cancerous tumors that need to be cut out quickly before they spread to vital organs of the state. Rival ideologies, such as liberalism and Islamism, are infectious diseases against which China’s population must be immunized. As Sheena Chestnut Greitens has shown, these medical metaphors justify targeting and “treating” people long before they display threatening symptoms.9 The clearest illustration is in Xinjiang, where China has extrajudicially locked up more than 1 million Uighurs in concentration camps.10 But China is applying preventive logic in foreign affairs, too, in ways that previous peaking powers would find familiar.

列宁陷阱

THE LENIN TRAP

中国的主要挑战不是修昔底德陷阱；这就是弗拉基米尔列宁所说的帝国主义，他预测这一过程将导致经济崩溃和战争。11列宁将帝国主义定义为资本主义国家试图在国外获得新的市场和资源它的本国经济因生产能力而变得过饱和。12除非该国找到新的市场，列宁的理论是，它将遭受经济停滞。增长将停止，工作岗位将消失，国内动荡将激增。为了避免这种命运，一个国家必须在国外开辟一个专属经济区——也就是一个帝国——在那里，其公司可以很容易地接触到消费者和廉价原材料。19 世纪后期的“争夺非洲”，欧洲列强在三十年内殖民了 90% 的非洲大陆，这是列宁理论的证据 A。

China’s main challenge isn’t the Thucydides Trap; it’s what Vladimir Lenin called imperialism, a process he predicted would lead to economic ruin and war.11 Lenin defined imperialism as a capitalist country’s attempt to secure new markets and resources abroad when its home economy becomes oversaturated with production capacity.12 Unless the country finds new markets, Lenin theorized, it would suffer economic stagnation. Growth would cease, jobs would vanish, and domestic unrest would spike. To avoid this fate, a country must carve out an exclusive economic zone abroad—aka, an empire—where its firms will have easy access to consumers and cheap raw materials. The late nineteenth century “scramble for Africa” in which European powers colonized 90 percent of the continent in thirty years was exhibit A for Lenin’s theory.

在命运的转折中，“共产主义”中国现在看起来已经为资本主义帝国主义做好了准备。它的经济充斥着数十年次级贷款产生的过剩产能。它过去倾销其产品的主要市场——北美、欧洲和日本——越来越不愿意吸收源源不断涌入的中国商品。自 2008 年以来，中国采取了两步走的计划来应对这些趋势。首先，向外国人提供超过 1 万亿美元的贷款，以便他们购买足够的中国商品和服务来维持 CCP Inc. 的经营。13其次，通过向研发投入资金、购买和窃取外国技术、利用补贴和贸易壁垒保护中国企业免受外国竞争，利用这些收益成为技术强国。北京希望，由此产生的创新浪潮将重振中国经济并增强其实力。

In a twist of fate, “Communist” China now looks primed for capitalist imperialism. Its economy is glutted with excess capacity generated by decades of subprime lending. The main markets where it used to dump its products—North America, Europe, and Japan—are increasingly unwilling to absorb an endless flood of Chinese goods. Since 2008, China has responded to these trends with a two-step plan. First, lend more than a trillion dollars to foreigners so they buy enough Chinese goods and services to keep CCP Inc. in business.13 Second, use the proceeds to become a technological powerhouse by pumping investment into R&D, buying and stealing foreign technology, and using subsidies and trade barriers to protect Chinese firms from foreign competition. The resulting surge of innovation, Beijing hopes, will reinvigorate China’s economy and boost its power.

然而，正如列宁预测的那样，在国内实行保护主义的同时向国外扩张，往往会激起外国的反对。当一个大国在保持其市场相对封闭的同时向海外倾销产品时，它会激怒贸易伙伴。结果是围绕市场、资源和地位的恶性竞争——有时是军事冲突。此外，当一个帝国主义国家让发展中国家背负债务并强迫他们购买其产品时，民族主义运动就会起来反抗。中共今天正在经历这些动态，因为富有各国重新考虑与中国的经济合作，而贫穷国家则要求为其 BRI 合同提供更好的条款或完全退出该倡议。但中国陷入了困境：它不能在不危及维持其政治制度的裙带资本主义的情况下放弃经济帝国主义或真正改革经济。14如果它放弃建立势力范围，它将在其竞争对手面前在战略上赤裸裸。因此，北京正在加倍努力寻求帝国。

As Lenin predicted, however, expanding abroad while practicing protectionism at home tends to incite foreign opposition. When a great power dumps products overseas while keeping its market relatively closed, it antagonizes trade partners. The result is vicious competition—sometimes military conflict—over markets, resources, and status. In addition, when an imperial power saddles developing nations with debt and coerces them to buy its products, nationalist movements rise up to resist. The CCP is experiencing these dynamics today, as rich countries rethink economic engagement with China while poor countries demand better terms for their BRI contracts or quit the initiative entirely. But China is trapped: It cannot abandon economic imperialism or truly reform its economy without endangering the crony capitalism that sustains its political system.14 If it gives up on creating spheres of influence, it will be strategically naked before its rivals. So Beijing is doubling down on a quest for empire.

此任务的一部分将涉及老式工具。随着对中国新殖民主义发展项目的抵制情绪的增加，北京可能不得不使用更严厉的手段——甚至是军事干预——来保护其非正式帝国。随着中国越来越担心资源的可用性和长补给线的安全，它可能会更加努力地建立更多的军事基地，部署一支全球海军，并掠夺南海等有争议的地区。换句话说，随着中国越来越依赖其帝国，它将更有可能通过招致国际冲突的粗暴方法来保卫自己的帝国。15这是一种令人担忧的可能性——但同样令人担忧的是一种新形式的中国帝国主义所带来的现实，其象征是一种称为“双循环”的政策。

Part of this quest will involve old-fashioned tools. As resistance to China’s neocolonial development projects grows, Beijing may feel compelled to use heavier-handed methods—even military intervention—to protect its informal empire. As China worries more about the availability of resources and the security of long supply lines, it could strive harder to build additional military bases, deploy a global navy, and plunder contested areas such as the South China Sea. As China becomes more dependent on its empire, in other words, it will become more likely to defend that empire through rough methods that invite international conflict.15 That’s a worrying possibility—but just as worrying is the reality posed by a new form of Chinese imperialism, symbolized by a policy called “dual circulation.”

“双循环”是一个看似无伤大雅的计划，却有着不祥的预兆。基本目标是增强中国经济自立（“内大循环”），进而撬开国外市场，从优势地位吸取国外技术和资源（“国际大循环”）。16通过在国内生产更多它需要的东西，并通过主导关键技术和资源的生产，中国可以在经济和地缘政治上发号施令。中国已经有利用经济杠杆对外国和公司施压的记录。17现在，它正准备通过成为重要产品和服务的供应商来大规模实施经济胁迫。中国必须习近平在 2020 年宣布：“打好关键核心技术攻坚战。”在另一次讲话中，他表示北京必须“增强我们在整个生产链上的优势”。18

“Dual circulation” is an innocuous sounding program with portentous implications. The basic goal is to enhance China’s economic self-reliance (the “great internal circulation”) and then pry open foreign markets and extract foreign technology and resources from a position of strength (the “great international circulation”).16 By producing more of what it needs at home, and by dominating the production of linchpin technologies and resources, China can dictate terms economically and geopolitically. China already has a record of exploiting pockets of economic leverage to turn the screws on foreign countries and companies.17 Now it is gearing up to wield economic coercion on a massive scale by becoming the supplier of vital products and services. China must “successfully fight tough battles for the key core technologies,” Xi declared in 2020. In another speech, he said that Beijing must “enhance our superiority across the entire production chain.”18

与中国的许多治国方略一样，双循环处于机遇与脆弱性的交汇处。在 2010 年代，中国通过使用巨额国家补贴帮助华为和其他公司开发关键产品并吞噬全球市场份额，从而在 5G 电信等领域取得领先地位。“我们在开关上睡着了，”五角大楼国防创新部主任迈克布朗承认道。19虽然美国逐渐意识到人工智能和合成生物学等技术的战略意义，而且美国政府与主要科技公司的关系冷淡，但北京正在启动一项由国家支持的重大举措——中国制造 2025 ——在重点竞争领域做大做强。20

Like much of China’s statecraft, dual circulation sits at the intersection of opportunity and vulnerability. During the 2010s, China bolted out to a lead in areas such as 5G telecommunications by using heavy state subsidies to help Huawei and other firms develop key products and gobble up global market share. “We were asleep at the switch,” admitted Mike Brown, director of the Pentagon’s Defense Innovation Unit.19 While the United States was gradually realizing the strategic implications of technologies such as artificial intelligence and synthetic biology, and while the U.S. government had a frosty relationship with major tech firms, Beijing was starting a major, state-backed push—Made in China 2025—to zoom ahead in key areas of competition.20

但这些初步成果尚未让中国克服对外国技术和资源的严重依赖。在当今充满敌意的地缘政治气候下，这种依赖可能是致命的。华盛顿及其盟友正试图通过阻止华为获得高端计算机芯片来“斩首”华为。21中国的航空业因美国和盟国对喷气发动机和航空电子设备的限制而停飞。22美国的关税抑制了中国的出口：习近平承认，特朗普的“贸易保护主义和经济霸权”正在“产生巨大影响”。23中国的竞争对手还有更多压力需要挤压：中国大约 70-80% 的石油、计算机芯片、高端传感器和先进医疗设备以及 90% 的先进制造设备都依赖进口。24《人民日报》写道，这种依赖是中国的“阿喀琉斯之踵”。25

But these initial gains haven’t yet allowed China to overcome its deep dependence on foreign technology and resources. In today’s hostile geopolitical climate, that dependence could prove fatal. Washington and its allies are trying to “decapitate” Huawei by blocking its access to high-end computer chips.21 China’s aviation industry is being grounded by U.S. and allied restrictions on jet engines and avionics.22 American tariffs have crimped China’s exports: Trump’s “trade protectionism and economic hegemony,” Xi admitted, were “having a great impact.”23 And there remain many more pressure points for China’s rivals to squeeze: China imports roughly 70–80 percent of its oil, computer chips, high-end sensors, and advanced medical devices as well as 90 percent of its advanced manufacturing equipment.24 This dependence, People’s Daily has written, is China’s “Achilles’ Heel.”25

因此，“双循环”不仅仅是一个流行语。这是从中国最初的技术中获取最大战略优势的努力在外国竞争对手扼杀北京的崛起之前取得进展。面对日益增长的全球敌意，中国唯一的选择是减少对外国人的依赖——让他们更加依赖中国。

“Dual circulation,” then, is more than a buzzword. It is an effort to wring maximum strategic advantage out of China’s initial technological advances before foreign rivals smother Beijing’s rise. Confronted with growing global animosity, China’s only option is to become less dependent on foreigners—and to make them more dependent on China.

根据政府文件，第一步是控制“瓶颈”技术的生产，填补可能导致中国供应链“在关键时刻”中断的“空白点”。26中国最新的五年计划于 2021 年 3 月公布，要求研发支出每年增长 7%，这一增长率高于军事预算的计划。中国的银行已拨出数百亿美元，向人工智能、量子计算、半导体、先进机器人和合成生物学等战略性行业的 1000 多家中国企业提供贷款。27目标是到本十年末，中国将生产 70% 的战略产业关键零部件。为了实现这一目标，北京正在迫使私营科技公司为国家服务，利用它们的数据，并要求它们开发新技术并将其交给政府——这是另一个听起来无伤大雅的学说“军民融合”的一部分。28

The first step, according to government documents, is to dominate production of “choke-point” technologies and fill “empty spots” that could cause Chinese supply chains to break “during crucial times.”26 China’s latest five-year plan, made public in March 2021, mandates 7 percent annual increases in R&D spending, a rate of growth faster than what is planned for the military budget. China’s banks have set aside tens of billions of dollars to lend to more than 1,000 Chinese firms in strategic industries, including artificial intelligence, quantum computing, semiconductors, advanced robotics, and synthetic biology.27 The objective is for China to produce 70 percent of key components in strategic industries by the end of the decade. To meet that goal, Beijing is pressing private tech firms into national service, tapping their data, and obliging them to develop new technologies and hand them over to the government—part of another innocuous-sounding doctrine called “civil-military fusion.”28

中国试图囤积全球数据的做法尤其能说明问题。2013年，习近平上台后不久就宣称：“浩瀚的数据海洋，就像工业化进程中的石油资源，蕴藏着巨大的生产力和机遇。谁掌握了大数据技术，谁就掌握了发展资源，谁就占了上风。” 29从那时起，北京通过将中国数据与世界隔离开来，同时购买和窃取其他国家的数据，从而成为世界上最强大的数据经纪人。一系列新法律要求所有在中国经营的公司将数据存储在本地，并向中共授予完全访问权限和控制权。如果没有北京方面的批准，外国公司甚至无法将有关来自中国的数据的备忘录发送到他们的总部。因此，苹果、特斯拉和其他主要科技公司都在争先恐后地建设专用的中国数据中心。与此同时，中国正在通过入侵跨国公司数据库和收购外国公司从国外获取数据。控制世界上最重要的资源是赤裸裸的重商主义战略。

China’s attempt to hoard global data is particularly telling. In 2013, shortly after coming to power, Xi declared: “The vast ocean of data, just like oil resources during industrialization, contains immense productive power and opportunities. Whoever controls big data technologies will control the resources for development and have the upper hand.”29 Since then, Beijing has become the world’s most powerful data broker by walling Chinese data off from the world while buying and stealing other countries’ data. A web of new laws requires all firms operating in China to store their data locally and grant full access and control to the CCP. Foreign firms can’t even send a memo about data from China to their home headquarters without Beijing’s blessing. As a result, Apple, Tesla, and other major tech firms are rushing to build dedicated Chinese data centers. Meanwhile, China is sucking up data from abroad by hacking multinational corporate databases and buying foreign companies. It is a nakedly mercantilist strategy to dominate the most important resource in the world.

中国利用数据的努力是更广泛地推动人工智能 (AI) 占据主导地位的一部分。人工智能是“人类正在努力的最重要的事情之一，”谷歌首席执行官桑达尔·皮查伊 (Sundar Pichai) 在 2018 年表示。“它比……更深刻。” . . 电或火。” 30撇开夸张不谈，专家们普遍认为人工智能将极大地提高经济生产力，并可能在未来 20 年内将增长率翻一番。它可以让最先进的军队更好地了解战场、提高决策速度并协调复杂的行动，从而改变各国的作战方式。谁能利用人工智能，谁就能“拥有决定性优势……。. . 未来几年，”国防部长马克·埃斯珀 (Mark Esper) 在 2020年警告说。 31人工智能将使新的、范式转变的间谍活动和虚假信息形式成为可能；它已经被纳入新的社会控制机制。

China’s efforts to harness data are part of a broader push for primacy in artificial intelligence (AI). AI is “one of the most important things humanity is working on,” Google CEO Sundar Pichai said in 2018. “It is more profound than . . . electricity or fire.”30 Hyperbole aside, experts generally agree that AI will create vast increases in economic productivity, perhaps doubling growth rates in the next twenty years. It could change how countries fight, by allowing the most advanced militaries to better understand the battlefield, enhance their speed of decision, and coordinate complex operations. Whoever harnesses AI could “have a decisive advantage . . . for years to come,” warned Secretary of Defense Mark Esper in 2020.31 AI will enable new, paradigm-shifting forms of espionage and disinformation; it is already being integrated into new mechanisms of social control.

难怪习近平力求在 2030 年之前让中国成为人工智能领域的世界领导者。32北京押注人工智能的主导地位将赋予它巨大的地缘政治影响力和行动自由——或许让它可以简单地跨越阻碍其前进的国家。

No wonder Xi seeks to make China the world leader in AI by 2030.32 Beijing is betting that AI dominance will give it great geopolitical leverage and freedom of action—perhaps allowing it simply to leapfrog countries blocking its advance.

作为其数字丝绸之路的一部分，中国经济战略的第二步是通过在全球数十个国家安装 5G 网络、光纤电缆和卫星系统来连接世界。33通过铺设重要的通信网络，北京将能够跟踪和存储通过这些网络的数据，从而获得巨大的企业和战略间谍机会，以及通过威胁操纵或关闭其网络来胁迫各国的机会。当英国考虑让华为建设其5G网络时，例如特朗普政府警告说，美国不会与一个通信如此容易受到损害的国家分享敏感情报。34对北京来说，这大概是重点：如果各国变得依赖受中共控制的公司提供的技术，它们如何帮助美国遏制中国？

The second step in China’s economic strategy is to wire the world by installing 5G networks, fiber-optic cables, and satellite systems in dozens of countries worldwide, as part of its Digital Silk Road.33 By laying down vital communications networks, Beijing will be able to track and store the data that passes through them, reaping enormous espionage opportunities, both corporate and strategic, and opportunities to coerce countries by threatening to manipulate or shut down their networks. When the United Kingdom was considering letting Huawei build its 5G network, for example, the Trump administration warned that America wouldn’t share sensitive intelligence with a country whose communications were so susceptible to being compromised.34 For Beijing, that was presumably the point: How can countries help America contain China if they have become dependent on technologies provided by companies in thrall to the CCP?

中国正走在主导全球网络的道路上。它是世界上最大的电信技术提供商。它已经成为全球12%的海底电缆的着陆点或供应商，承载着95%的国际数据。华为声称与140个国家有云计算合同；另一家中国公司亨通集团安装了全球 15% 的光纤。35中国的北斗卫星网络已被数十个国家采用，其覆盖范围超过了全球 165 个首都城市，超过了美国全球定位系统 (GPS)。36中国在全球网络中的收益可能会持续很长时间，因为更换电信和卫星基础设施的成本极其高昂。一个国家一旦采用了中国的制度，基本上就被锁定了。

China is well on its way to dominating global networks. It is the world’s largest provider of telecommunications technology. It has already become a landing point or supplier for 12 percent of the world’s submarine cables, which carry 95 percent of international data. Huawei claims to have cloud computing contracts with 140 countries; another Chinese company, Hengtong Group, has installed 15 percent of the world’s fiber optics.35 China’s BeiDou satellite network has been adopted by dozens of countries and provides greater coverage over 165 of the world’s capital cities than does the U.S. Global Positioning System (GPS).36 China’s gains in global networks could be long-lasting, because telecom and satellite infrastructures are extremely expensive to replace. Once a country adopts China’s systems, it is basically locked in.

将此视为一种反包围战略：如果中国能够将整个欧亚大陆乃至更远的国家纳入其技术控制范围，它就可以摆脱其陷入的经济和地缘政治陷阱。

Think of this as a counter-encirclement strategy: If China can draw countries throughout Eurasia and beyond into its technological grasp, it can escape the economic and geopolitical trap in which it has become ensnared.

最后，中国正在为先进的微芯片、物联网、云计算、大数据、5G、智能医疗和人工智能等下一代技术制定国际技术标准。37在大多数这些行业中，只有一套全球标准，制定这些标准的国家可能会统治市场，因为其产品已经符合要求的规格。中国人认识到这个优势，有一句话：三流做产品，二流做技术，一流做标准。中共也有一个计划，中国标准 2035，致力于制定国际技术标准。截至 2021 年，北京牵头联合国 15 个科技相关机构中的 4 个（与美国牵头的机构相比），向国际机构提交的标准制定提案比任何其他国家都多。“全球技术标准仍在形成过程中，”中国国家标准化管理委员会委员戴红在 2018 年表示，“这给了中国的行业和标准超越世界的机会。” 38

Finally, China is racing to set international technical standards for next-generation technology such as advanced microchips, the internet of things, cloud computing, big data, 5G, intelligent health care, and AI.37 In most of these industries, there will be only one set of global standards, and the country that sets them will likely rule the market because its products will already meet the required specifications. The Chinese recognize this advantage and have a saying: third-tier companies make products, second-tier companies make technology, top-tier companies set standards. The CCP also has a plan, China Standards 2035, dedicated to dictating international technical standards. As of 2021, Beijing led four of the fifteen science- and technology-related agencies of the United Nations (compared to one led by the United States) and submitted more standard-setting proposals to international bodies than any other country. “Global technical standards are still in the process of being formed,” said Dai Hong, a member of China’s National Standardization Management Committee, in 2018. “This gives China’s industry and standards the opportunity to surpass the world.”38

这里的大胆是非凡的：如果这个现代帝国主义取得成功，中国将统治一个新的“中国圈”，其中曾经由西方主导的全球贸易和创新网络将聚集在北京周围。这种情况让许多美国战略家夜不能寐。但另一种可能同样令人不安的情况是，如果北京的努力只取得部分成功，使中国强大到足以恐吓和施压许多国家，但又不足以让人们对其长期前景感到安全。届时，世界将面对一个更强大但仍然苦恼的中国，一个易燃的组合。

The boldness here is remarkable: If this modern-day imperialism succeeds, China will rule over a new “sinosphere,” in which global networks of trade and innovation once dominated by the West will cluster around Beijing. This scenario keeps many American strategists up at night. But another scenario that could be just as troubling is if Beijing’s efforts succeed only partially, leaving China strong enough to scare and pressure many countries, but not strong enough to feel secure about its long-term prospects. The world would then face a more muscular but still distressed China, a combustible combination.

中国领导人知道这种部分成功的可能性很明显：国际上对华为的强烈反对威胁到他们安装全球电信核心的计划。鉴于北京在国内微芯片产业上花费了十年和数百亿美元，但仍然依赖进口来满足该国 80% 的计算需求，中共对其新的创新计划也没有太大信心。39中国还在生物技术上投入了数百亿美元，但其 COVID-19 疫苗的质量不及美国和其他民主国家生产的神奇药物。40尽管北京在监控等相对狭窄的人工智能应用领域取得了长足进步，但在更广泛的人工智能子领域和用途方面，它仍然远远落后于美国。41鉴于中国在摆脱列宁陷阱方面面临的障碍，中共正在通过磨练其他影响力工具，包括强大的意识形态武器，来对冲赌注。

China’s leaders know this partial-success scenario is a distinct possibility: The international backlash against Huawei threatens their scheme to install the guts of global telecommunications. Nor can the CCP have much confidence in its new innovation initiative, given that Beijing spent a decade and tens of billions of dollars on a domestic microchip industry, yet still relies on imports for 80 percent of the country’s computing needs.39 China also spent tens of billions of dollars on biotech, yet its COVID-19 vaccines were lapped in quality by the wonder drugs produced in America and other democratic countries.40 And while Beijing has made great progress in a relatively narrow swath of AI applications, such as surveillance, it still lags significantly behind the United States across a wider array of AI subfields and uses.41 Given the obstacles China faces in breaking free of Lenin’s trap, the CCP is hedging its bets by honing other tools of influence, including powerful ideological weapons.

民主预防

DEMOCRACY PREVENTION

在二战最黑暗的时刻，世界上大概有十几个民主国家。42直到 1989 年，专制政府的数量还是民主政府的两倍。然而，20 年后，民主国家的数量比专制国家多了 100 对 78，世界上生活在专制国家的人口比例下降了一半。从美国的角度来看，民主在全球的进步是战后时代最有希望的发展之一。从中国领导人的角度来看，这是一个明显的迹象，表明自由世界秩序被操纵以反对他们的政府形式，需要在它摧毁他们的政权之前进行改变。

At the darkest moment of World War II, there were perhaps a dozen democracies in the world.42 As late as 1989, there were twice as many autocratic governments as democracies. Twenty years later, however, democracies outnumbered autocracies 100 to 78, and the share of the world’s population living under autocracy had fallen by half. From a U.S. perspective, democracy’s global advance was one of the most hopeful developments of the postwar era. From the perspective of China’s leaders, it was a clear sign that the liberal world order was rigged against their form of government and needed to be changed before it destroyed their regime.

按照北京的说法，问题始于战后初期，当时美国利用其主导地位将激进的自由主义思想注入国际机构。例如，联合国 1948 年的《世界人权宣言》就是以美国《人权法案》为蓝本。它指出，所有人生来都是自由的，并有权推翻不尊重这种自由的政府。在后来的几十年里，美国帮助许多国家建立了民主制度，包括中国的一些邻国：日本、韩国和台湾。不断扩大的全球民主团体随后使用军事力量、经济制裁以及一系列媒体和人权组织来破坏数十个独裁国家——不仅仅是锡锅独裁者，43

According to Beijing’s narrative, the problem started at the beginning of the postwar period, when the United States exploited its dominant position to inject radical liberal ideas into international institutions. For example, the UN’s 1948 Universal Declaration on Human Rights was modeled on the U.S. Bill of Rights. It states that all humans are born free and have the right to overthrow governments that fail to respect that freedom. In later decades, America helped foster democratic institutions in numerous countries, including some of China’s neighbors: Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan. The expanding global posse of democracies subsequently used military force, economic sanctions, and an array of media and human rights organizations to undermine dozens of autocracies—not just tin-pot dictators, but also the Soviet Union and nearly China itself in 1989. “Capitalist forces will always use subversion to exterminate socialist countries and the socialist system,” CCP officials wrote.43

尽管中国领导人长期以来对这种意识形态压力感到恼火，但只要中国经济繁荣、外围稳定，这种压力是可以忍受的。由于 1990 年代和 2000 年代 GDP 的增长速度是民主平均水平的三倍，北京很容易说服国内外人们相信威权主义最适合中国，如果不是对其他国家的话。44

Although PRC leaders long chafed at this ideological pressure, it was bearable so long as China enjoyed a booming economy and a stable periphery. With a GDP growing three times faster than the democratic average in the 1990s and 2000s, it was easy for Beijing to persuade people at home and abroad that authoritarianism was best for China, if not for other countries.44

但现在，随着经济放缓和国际敌意的酝酿，独裁不再是一件容易的事。当他们的银行账户和国家的国际地位膨胀时，中国公民愿意放弃政治权利，但他们是否会在更严酷的条件下这样做是一个悬而未决的问题。对于中国的千禧一代来说，这个问题尤其紧迫，他们只知道向上的经济和国际流动性。当这群人在 80 年代诞生时，邓小平警告说，打开“窗户”呼吸西方商业的“新鲜空气”也会让以诱人的思想和腐败影响的形式出现的“苍蝇”。45他没有说，但非常清楚的是，快速增长和与西方的接触也可能改变中国人民，以某种方式提高他们的期望，而该政权有朝一日可能难以满足。

But now, with a slowing economy and brewing international hostility, autocracy is no longer an easy sell. China’s citizens were willing to forgo political rights when their bank accounts and their country’s international status were swelling, but it’s an open question whether they would do so under harsher conditions. That question is especially pressing with regard to China’s millennials, who have known nothing but upward economic and international mobility. When that cohort was being born in the 1980s, Deng Xiaoping warned that opening the “window” to breathe the “fresh air” of Western commerce would also allow in “flies” in the form of seductive ideas and corrupting influences.45 What he did not say, but knew very well, was that rapid growth and engagement with the West could also change the Chinese people, raising their expectations in ways that the regime might one day struggle to satisfy.

中国的统治者也很早就明白政治学家已经用经验证明了什么：独裁政权往往一波三折，因为一个国家的革命活动会激发其他国家的民众起义。46民主的多米诺骨牌效应在 1989 年推翻了整个东欧的共产主义政权。2011 年在突尼斯自焚的一名水果商贩在中东的大部分地区引发了反抗。教训是，任何地方的革命都可能对任何地方的专制制度构成威胁——甚至对几周甚至几天前看似稳定的政权也是如此。47

China’s rulers also have long understood what political scientists have proven empirically: Autocracies often fall in waves, as revolutionary activity in one country inspires popular uprisings in others.46 A democratic domino effect brought down Communist regimes across Eastern Europe in 1989. A fruit vendor who immolated himself in Tunisia in 2011 set much of the Middle East aflame in revolt. The lesson is that revolution anywhere can be a threat to autocracy everywhere—even to regimes that seemed stable weeks or even days before.47

这种潜伏的威胁是中共在过去十年中变得更加镇压的原因——为什么它主动出狱持不同政见者，动员安全部队，审查信息，并先发制人。然而，中国现在已经足够强大，除了屈服于外国压力之外，它还有其他选择。习近平认为，如果威权主义盛行而民主制度失灵，中共的国内权力将会增强，因为同为暴君的人不会因侵犯人权而惩罚中国，中国人民也不会效仿混乱的自由制度。他认为，防止其他国家的反威权叛乱将减少它们在中国爆发的可能性。他认为，让国外的批评者闭嘴将限制中共在国内面临的挑战。因此，习近平正在采取行动，通过削弱海外民主来确保他的政权。

This lurking threat is why the CCP has become so much more repressive in the past decade—why it has worked proactively to jail dissidents, mobilize security forces, censor information, and preempt popular unrest. Yet China is now strong enough that it has options besides hunkering down against foreign pressure. Xi believes that the CCP’s domestic power will be enhanced if authoritarianism is prevalent and democracies are dysfunctional, because fellow despots won’t punish China for human rights abuses, and the Chinese people won’t want to emulate chaotic liberal systems. He thinks that preventing anti-authoritarian revolts in other countries will reduce the possibility that they might erupt in China. And he believes that silencing critics abroad will limit the challenges the CCP faces at home. So Xi is moving to secure his regime by rolling back democracy overseas.

近年来，中国发动了意识形态攻势，并在全球范围内进行镇压。北京现在每年花费数十亿美元用于非政府组织、媒体机构、外交官、顾问、黑客和贿赂的“反民主工具包”，所有这些都旨在支持独裁者并在民主国家中挑拨离间。48尽管中国曾经担心将自己与外国民众的骚乱隔离开来，但现在它的目标是首先防止这种骚乱的爆发。49中共为其他专制国家提供枪支、金钱和免受联合国制裁的保护。中国官员向他们的威权兄弟们提供防暴装备和如何建立监视国家的指导。北京还通过使用大量全球媒体来宣传非自由统治的成就，辩称民主是新殖民主义的强加，并强调美国的超党派偏见，从而对威权政权进行干涉。

China has gone on the ideological offensive in recent years and taken its repression global. Beijing now spends billions of dollars annually on an “anti-democratic toolkit” of NGOs, media outlets, diplomats, advisers, hackers, and bribes all designed to prop up autocrats and sow discord in democracies.48 Whereas China once worried about insulating itself from foreign popular unrest, it now aims to prevent that unrest from breaking out in the first place.49 The CCP provides fellow autocracies with guns, money, and protection from UN sanctions. Chinese officials offer their authoritarian brethren riot-control gear and pointers in how to build a surveillance state. Beijing also runs interference for authoritarian regimes by using a vast array of global media to tout the accomplishments of illiberal rule, argue that democracy is a neocolonial imposition, and highlight hyper-partisanship in the United States.

人们可能很容易将中国的民主预防努力斥为“一如既往的世界政治”。毕竟，自从俄罗斯、奥地利和普鲁士帮助镇压法国大革命以来，独裁者就一直在勾结以遏制自由主义。弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 领导的俄罗斯正在前苏联及其他地区推行类似的议程。但出于三个原因，中国的意识形态攻击更为深刻。

It might be tempting to dismiss China’s democracy prevention efforts as “world politics as usual.” After all, autocrats have been colluding to hold liberalism at bay ever since Russia, Austria, and Prussia helped crush the French Revolution. Vladimir Putin’s Russia is pursuing a similar agenda in the former Soviet Union and beyond. But China’s ideological assault is more profound, for three reasons.

首先，它利用了最近令人不安的趋势。自第二次世界大战以来，漫长的历史弧线可能已经转向更大的自由。但根据自由之家编制的统计数据，自 2006 年以来，威权主义每年都在蔓延，而民主在倒退。50民主倒退的原因仍然存在争议，但这无助于主要民主国家度过了新时代的头二十年。千禧年发动了一场丑陋的反恐战争，并从大萧条以来最严重的金融危机中挣扎。由此产生的“民主衰退”给了中国一个意识形态机会之窗。北京提出的反自由主义批评对幻想破灭的民主人士更有说服力，对全世界有抱负的独裁者更有用。51中国的铁拳正在敲开一扇敞开的大门。

First, it capitalizes on a disturbing recent trend. The long arc of history may have bended, since World War II, toward greater freedom. But according to the statistics compiled by Freedom House, authoritarianism has been spreading, and democracy receding, every year since 2006.50 The causes of democratic backsliding remain disputed, but it didn’t help that leading democracies spent the first two decades of the new millennium waging an ugly war on terror and reeling from the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. The resulting “democratic recession” has given China a window of ideological opportunity. The anti-liberal critique Beijing offers has become more persuasive to disillusioned democrats, and more useful to aspiring autocrats, the world over.51 China’s iron fist is knocking on an open door.

其次，中国的全球影响力比以往任何一个不自由的大国都更为普遍。北京在主要国际组织中取得领导地位的成功现在使其能够将自由秩序的机构变成反民主影响的工具。一个典型的例子：当白俄罗斯公然违反国际规范，在 2021 年迫使一架载有通缉持不同政见者的客机坠毁时，猜猜哪个国家领导着国际民用航空组织并帮助保护这个残暴政权免受谴责？52此外，北京的 14 亿消费者赋予它一种能力——这是苏联从未有过的——将其镇压做法输出到世界。

Second, China’s global reach is more pervasive than that of any prior illiberal power. Beijing’s success in taking leadership positions in major international organizations now allows it to turn organs of the liberal order into tools of anti-democratic influence. A case in point: When Belarus flagrantly violated international norms by forcing down an airliner that was carrying a wanted dissident in 2021, guess which country headed the International Civil Aviation Organization and helped protect that brutal regime from censure?52 In addition, Beijing’s 1.4 billion consumers give it an ability—which the Soviets never had—to export its repressive practices to the world.

例如，在 2020 年，北京对澳大利亚进行报复——澳大利亚曾要求对 COVID-19 的起源进行国际调查——不仅对其经济实施制裁，还要求堪培拉通过压制批评人士的声音来破坏其民主。报纸和智囊团。同样，当中国对谴责新疆镇压的欧洲政客和分析人士实施制裁时，当它迫使万豪解雇一名喜欢在推特上提到西藏的美国员工时，或者当它通过法律时威胁要惩罚世界上任何地方支持香港政治自由的任何人，它正在利用其市场力量攻击世界上一些最先进社会的言论自由——民主的基础。53

In 2020, for example, Beijing retaliated against Australia—which had committed the affront of asking for an international inquiry into the origins of COVID-19—not just by imposing sanctions on its economy but also by demanding that Canberra gut its democracy by silencing critical newspapers and think tanks. Likewise, when China applies sanctions against European politicians and analysts who condemn the repression in Xinjiang, when it compels Marriott to fire an American employee who likes a tweet referring to Tibet, or when it passes a law that threatens to punish anyone, anywhere in the world, who supports political freedom in Hong Kong, it is using its market power to attack free speech—the very foundation of democracy—in some of the most advanced societies in the world.53

第三个也是最重要的推动中国努力的因素是正在进行的数字革命。54想一想 Apple、Amazon、Facebook、Google 和 Twitter 的数据收集和消息传递能力。现在想象一下，在中共手中。通过结合人工智能、大数据、网络、生物识别、语音和面部识别技术，中国政府正在开创一个系统，让独裁者能够了解他们臣民的一切——人们在说什么，在看什么；他们和谁一起出去玩；他们喜欢什么，不喜欢什么；以及它们在任何给定时间的位置。该系统将允许政权通过限制他们获得信贷、教育、就业、医疗、电信和旅行的机会来立即惩戒公民——以及追捕人们以进行更中世纪形式的惩罚。

The third and most important factor supercharging China’s efforts is the ongoing digital revolution.54 Think of the data-collection and messaging power of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Google, and Twitter. Now imagine that in the hands of the CCP. By combining AI, big data, and cyber, biometric, and speech- and facial-recognition technologies, the Chinese government is pioneering a system that will allow dictators to know everything about their subjects—what people are saying and viewing; whom they hang out with; what they like and dislike; and where they are located at any given time. That system will allow regimes to discipline citizens instantly by restricting their access to credit, education, employment, medical care, telecommunications, and travel—as well as to hunt people down for more medieval forms of punishment.
