这场技术革命使镇压比以往任何时候都更容易负担和更有效，从而有可能颠覆民主与威权主义之间的全球平衡。55独裁者不再依赖昂贵的（并且可能是反叛的）军队来残酷对待和洗脑不满的民众，现在独裁者将拥有更便宜和更阴险的控制手段。数以亿计的不眨眼的摄像头可以取代数百万的间谍。面部识别和人工智能技术可以快速分类视频源并识别麻烦制造者。机器人可以提供针对特定群体或个人量身定制的宣传。恶意软件可以通过看似无害的应用程序或链接安装在计算机上，然后政府黑客可以破坏持不同政见者的计算机网络或收集他们的操作数据。反过来，这些信息可以用来通过贿赂他们的领导人或会见他们更多的人来联合抵抗运动。无害的要求。或者，当局可以打印一份 AI 汇编的涉嫌激进分子名单，然后杀死名单上的所有人。

This technological revolution threatens to upend the global balance between democracy and authoritarianism by making repression more affordable and effective than ever before.55 Instead of relying on expensive (and potentially rebellious) armies to brutalize and brainwash a resentful population, an autocrat will now have cheaper and more insidious means of control. Millions of spies can be replaced with hundreds of millions of unblinking cameras. Facial-recognition and artificial intelligence technologies can rapidly sort through video feeds and identify troublemakers. Bots can deliver propaganda tailored to specific groups or individuals. Malware can be installed on computers through seemingly innocuous apps or links, and then government hackers can crash the computer networks of dissidents or gather data on their operations. That information, in turn, can be used to coopt resistance movements by bribing their leaders or meeting their more innocuous demands. Alternatively, authorities can print out an AI-assembled list of alleged activists and kill everyone on it.

这种“数字威权主义”的邪恶天才在于，大多数人似乎可以自由地过他们的日常生活。实际上，国家将审查他们看到的一切并跟踪他们所做的一切。对于老派威权主义，人们至少知道压迫来自何处。但现在，人们可以通过社交媒体提供个性化内容的隐形算法来推动和哄骗人们。在过去的时代，独裁者不得不在资助敢死队或实现经济增长之间做出艰难的选择。然而今天，镇压不仅负担得起，而且可能有利可图，因为促进严格社会控制的“智能城市”技术也可用于改善基础设施、诊断疾病和让火车准时运行。

The evil genius of this “digital authoritarianism” is that most people will be seemingly free to go about their daily lives. In reality, the state will censor everything they see and track everything they do. With old-school authoritarianism, one at least knew where the oppression was coming from. But now people can be nudged and cajoled by invisible algorithms delivering personalized content through social media. In past eras, autocrats had to make tough choices between funding death squads or delivering economic growth. Today, however, repression is not only affordable, it may be profitable, because the same “smart-city” technologies that facilitate strict social control can also be used to improve infrastructure, diagnose diseases, and make the trains run on time.

不用说，这些技术是暴君的梦想。“独裁者可能不想要中国的意识形态，”负责政策的美国国防部副部长科林卡尔说，“但他们确实想要它的方法论。” 认识到这一需求，截至 2020 年，中国公司已经在 80 多个国家/地区销售和运营监控系统。56随着中共在国内外感受到越来越大的威胁，我们完全有理由期望北京将数字威权主义输出得越来越远。许多国家已经想要它，而中国有强大的工具来迫使那些不想这样做的国家。想进入中国市场？让华为为您安装 5G 网络的核心组件。想要中国贷款？在你的首都接受中国的监控技术。

Needless to say, these technologies are a tyrant’s dream. “Dictators may not want China’s ideology,” says U.S. under secretary of defense for policy Colin Kahl, “but they do want its methodology.” Recognizing this demand, Chinese companies were already selling and operating surveillance systems in more than 80 countries, as of 2020.56 As the CCP feels increasingly threatened at home and abroad, there is every reason to expect Beijing to export digital authoritarianism farther and wider. Many countries already want it, and China has powerful tools to compel those that don’t. Want access to China’s market? Let Huawei install the core components of your 5G network. Want a Chinese loan? Accept Chinese surveillance technology in your capital.

随着越来越多的政府与北京合作，中国的全球监控国家的影响范围将会扩大。57既有的专制政体将变得更加极权，而一些民主政体将滑入专制阵营。在 1990 年代如此普遍的自由主义信念，即民主将不可避免地在世界范围内传播，将被颠覆。

As more governments partner with Beijing, the reach of China’s global surveillance-state will grow.57 Existing autocracies will become more totalitarian, and some democracies will drift into the authoritarian camp. The liberal belief, so common in the 1990s, that democracy would inevitably spread around the world will be upended.

令人欣慰的神话也将如此，即人类已经进化到超越大规模暴行的地步。数字威权主义不能替代古拉格和种族灭绝；它是一个推动因素。政治学家表明，当独裁政权加强数字镇压时，他们也会进行更多的酷刑和谋杀。58原因很简单：随着机器处理日常簿记和监视，步兵可以自由地关注专制统治的实际方面，例如种族清洗和殴打持不同政见者。

So will the comforting myth that humanity has evolved past the point of mass atrocities. Digital authoritarianism is not a substitute for gulags and genocide; it is an enabler. Political scientists have shown that when dictatorships ramp up digital repression, they also engage in more torture and murder.58 The reason is simple: With machines handling day-to-day bookkeeping and surveillance, foot soldiers are free to focus on the physical aspects of authoritarian rule, such as ethnic cleansing and beating dissidents into submission.

看看新疆，智慧城市与集中营并存。59中国安全人员驻守在营地并处理“再教育”和强制绝育，而摄像头、生物识别扫描仪和强制性手机应用程序将数据输入计算机，以密切关注该省发生的一切。算法会将摄像机镜头与警察在“健康检查”时拍摄的快照、血液样本和 DNA 拭子进行匹配。当维吾尔人到达他们社区的边缘时，他们的手机会自动向当局发出警报。当他们加油时，系统会检查他们是否是车主。如果他们试图逃离该省，警察会被派往他们的家人和朋友家门口。如果他们以某种方式逃到国外，也不一定能逃脱：中国的专制盟友，即使是埃及等穆斯林占多数的国家，

Just look at Xinjiang, where smart cities exist side-by-side with concentration camps.59 Chinese security officers man the camps and handle the “reeducation” and forced sterilization, while cameras, biometric scanners, and mandatory cell-phone apps feed data into computers that keep tabs on everything that happens in the province. Algorithms match camera footage with snapshots, blood samples, and DNA swabs taken by police at “health checks.” When Uighurs reach the edge of their neighborhood, their cell phones automatically alert authorities. When they pump gas, the system checks whether they are the car’s owner. If they try to flee the province, police are dispatched to the doorsteps of their family and friends. If they somehow make it abroad, they aren’t guaranteed an escape: China’s authoritarian allies, even those in Muslim-majority countries such as Egypt, are starting to use Chinese surveillance technology to track down and deport Uighurs back into Beijing’s clutches.

一些专家仍然坚信，中国实际上并未对民主构成重大威胁，因为它并不像苏联那样真正关心其他国家是否由共产党统治。60或者他们争辩说，即使一些软弱的、部分民主的国家消失在数字铁幕之后，像美国这样丰富而稳固的民主国家将作为自由孤岛而存在。

Some experts still cling to the belief that China doesn’t actually pose a major threat to democracy, because it doesn’t really care—as the Soviet Union did—whether other countries are ruled by Communists.60 Or they argue that rich and consolidated democracies such as the United States will endure as islands of liberty, even if some weak, partial democracies disappear behind a digital iron curtain.

这大错特错了。数字威权主义正在蔓延进入自由世界的心脏。使用数字工具来操纵公众舆论、妖魔化反对者并动员支持者的暴力暴徒对于在民主国家寻求权力的人和独裁者一样具有吸引力。在当今许多民主国家盛行的部落政治气候中尤其如此。在整个自由世界，党派分歧已飙升至历史高位，公众对民主制度的信任已降至 1930 年代以来的最低点，主要政党公开提倡反民主法律。61政治土壤已经成熟，威权主义的元素可以生根发芽，中国和俄罗斯正在用数字虚假信息为其施肥，这些虚假信息由机器人大量制造，并在 Facebook 上成为全球数百万人的主要内容。62随着美中竞争的激烈程度飙升，北京使用支持人工智能的深度造假和其他形式的虚假信息来削弱和破坏其对手的动机也将如此。

This couldn’t be more wrong. Digital authoritarianism is creeping into the heart of the liberal world. The use of digital tools to manipulate public opinion, demonize opponents, and mobilize violent mobs of supporters is just as alluring for someone seeking power in a democracy as it is for a dictator. That is especially true in the tribal political climate that prevails in many democracies today. Across the liberal world, partisan divisions have surged to historic highs, public trust in democratic institutions has sunk to lows not seen since the 1930s, and major parties are openly advocating anti-democratic laws.61 The political soil is ripe for elements of authoritarianism to take root, and China and Russia are fertilizing it with digital disinformation, churned out by bots and mainlined into the Facebook feeds of millions around the world.62 As the intensity of the U.S.-China rivalry spikes, so will Beijing’s incentive to use AI-enabled deep fakes and other forms of disinformation to weaken and undermine its adversary.

即使美国和其他主要民主国家没有成为这种意识形态攻势的牺牲品，它们的权力和安全也会在一个更加专制的世界中被削弱。美国试图环绕中国的战略链条中最强大的一环是民主国家，这并非巧合。北京将俄罗斯和伊朗等暴政列为最亲密的朋友也不是巧合——事实上，中国和俄罗斯破坏和削弱世界民主的努力是齐头并进的。民主国家都需要一个有利于维护其自由制度的国际环境。威权主义者都需要一个保护他们免受自由颠覆力量侵害的世界。不同版本的国内秩序产生不同的国际秩序愿景。63如果中国成功地将更多国家拉入专制阵营，将改变战略平衡，削弱动员起来反对它的联盟。

Even if America and other leading democracies don’t fall prey to this ideological offensive, their power and security would be diminished in a more authoritarian world. It is no coincidence that the strongest links in the strategic chain America is trying to wrap around China are democracies. Nor is it a coincidence that Beijing counts tyrannies such as Russia and Iran among its closest friends—and indeed, Chinese and Russian efforts to disrupt and degrade the world’s democracies go hand-in-hand. Democracies all need an international environment conducive to preserving their liberal institutions. Authoritarians all need a world that protects them from the subversive forces of freedom. Different versions of domestic order produce different visions of international order.63 If China succeeds in pulling more countries into the authoritarian camp, it will shift the strategic balance and weaken the coalition mobilizing against it.

最根本的是，专制政体在妖魔化民主政体方面具有既得利益。独裁者不希望他们的人民推崇民主制度并要求自由。集会的最佳方式独裁政权周围的公民会激起对主要民主国家的仇恨，而这需要源源不断的意识形态冲突。完全可以预见，世界上最臭名昭著的强人——习近平、普京、哈梅内伊、金正恩、阿萨德、埃尔多安、欧尔班、卢卡申科——将自己描绘成传统、等级制度和秩序的捍卫者，反对腐朽的民主西方。随着中国扩大威权主义者的队伍，世界将成为美国及其民主盟友的一个更寒酸的地方。64国际冲突将激增，不仅在思想层面，而且在军事领域，因为血腥的民族主义与暴力的复仇主义齐头并进。令人担忧的是，这种动态已经开始显现。

Most fundamentally, autocracies have a vested interest in demonizing democracies. Dictators don’t want their people admiring democratic institutions and demanding freedom. The best way to rally citizens around an authoritarian regime is to inspire hatred of leading democracies, and that requires a steady stream of ideological conflict. It’s entirely predictable that the world’s most notorious strongmen—Xi, Putin, Khamenei, Kim, Assad, Erdogan, Orbán, Lukashenko—portray themselves as defenders of tradition, hierarchy, and order against a decadent democratic West. As China enlarges the ranks of authoritarians, the world will become a shabbier place for the United States and its democratic allies.64 International conflicts will proliferate, and not just at the level of ideas, but also in the military realm, because blood-and-soil nationalism goes hand-in-hand with violent revanchism. That dynamic, worryingly, is already playing out.

窗户与战争

WINDOWS AND WAR

俄罗斯于 2022 年 2 月全面入侵乌克兰，震惊了世界，提醒世界各地的领导人地缘政治竞争很容易演变成大规模的直接军事冲突。但俄罗斯并不是唯一能够进行灾难性侵略的修正主义国家——甚至不是最强大的国家。随着这十年的继续，中国也将感受到罢工的冲动。

Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 shocked the world, by reminding leaders everywhere that geopolitical competition can all-too-easily turn into outright military conflict on an epic scale. But Russia isn’t the only revisionist state—or even the most powerful one—capable of catastrophic aggression. China will also feel the urge to strike as this decade goes on.

中共在地缘政治上想要什么并不神秘，因为它几十年来一直想要同样的东西：让中国重新成为一个整体，把东海和南海变成中国的湖泊，并夺取地区首要地位作为全球大国的跳板。这些目标是固定的：问题是中国将如何追求这些目标。

There is no mystery about what the CCP wants geopolitically, because it has wanted the same things for decades: to make China whole again, turn the East China and South China Seas into Chinese lakes, and grab regional primacy as a springboard to global power. These goals are fixed: The question is how China will pursue them.

在 1990 年代和 2000 年代，北京的做法大多是和平和耐心的。中国对不断增长的经济充满信心，并担心过早地与西方开战，因此主要通过非对抗性手段来实现其目标。中国通过炫耀其广阔的市场，不费一枪一弹地从外国竞争对手手中夺取了地盘。英国人1997 年交还香港。1999 年葡萄牙放弃澳门。1991 年至 2019 年间，六个国家与中国解决了领土争端，另外两个国家与台湾断交以确保与北京的关系。中国实施“和平崛起”战略，成效显着。65

In the 1990s and 2000s, Beijing’s approach was mostly peaceful and patient. Confident in a growing economy, and wary of prematurely picking a fight with the West, China pursued its aims primarily through nonconfrontational means. By flaunting its vast market, China wrested territory from foreign rivals without firing a shot. The British handed back Hong Kong in 1997. Portugal gave up Macao in 1999. Half a dozen countries settled their territorial disputes with China between 1991 and 2019, and two dozen other countries cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan to secure relations with Beijing. China carried out a “peaceful rise” strategy, and it worked well.65

那些日子结束了。其他国家对在中国赚的钱越来越不感兴趣，而越来越担心北京的掠夺。在全球范围内，情绪已经从谨慎欢迎中国崛起转变为害怕和反对中国崛起，这向习近平提出了一个关键问题：如果收复领土和扩大影响力的和平途径正在关闭，是时候开始展示中国的军事力量了在过去的三十年里花了 3 万亿美元建设？

Those days are over. Other countries are becoming less enthralled by the money to be made in China and more concerned about Beijing’s predation. Globally, the mood has shifted from cautiously welcoming China’s rise to fearing and opposing it, and that has raised a pivotal question for Xi: If the peaceful route to reclaiming territory and expanding influence is closing, is it time to start flexing the military muscle China has spent $3 trillion building over the past three decades?

这就是过去达到顶峰的大国所做的，中国的历史表明它将追随他们的脚步。无数研究分析了中国何时以及为何使用武力，得出的结论都是一致的：中国打仗，不是在崛起的时候，而是在安全恶化、议价能力下降的时候。66换句话说，中共通常使用武力来利用关闭的机会窗口或避免打开的漏洞窗口。当被竞争对手逼入绝境时，中国不会坐以待毙。相反，它通常会在其战略形势变得更糟之前首先开火以获得战术优势。事实上，中国经常对实力强大的敌人发动战争，并不期望赢得最大的战斗。目标可能只是通过艰苦的战斗和表现出造成——并遭受——巨大伤亡的意愿来让敌人退缩。该信息通常既针对站在场边的对手，也针对在擂台上与中国纠缠的敌人。

That’s what past peaking powers did, and China’s history suggests it will follow in their footsteps. Numerous studies have analyzed when and why the PRC uses force, and they all reach the same conclusion: China fights, not when it is rising, but when its security is deteriorating and its bargaining strength is declining.66 In other words, the CCP typically uses force to exploit a closing window of opportunity or avoid an opening window of vulnerability. When cornered by rivals, China does not wait to be attacked. Instead, it usually shoots first to gain tactical advantage before its strategic situation gets even worse. In fact, China often starts wars against superior foes with little expectation of winning the biggest battles. The goal may simply be making an enemy back off by fighting hard and demonstrating a willingness to inflict—and suffer—enormous casualties. That message is usually directed as much to rivals standing on the sidelines as it is to the enemy tangling with China in the ring.

只要看看中国的任何一场战争。1950 年底，一波又一波的中国士兵袭击了驻韩美军，因为他们担心美国人会征服朝鲜并在那里建立军事基地。中国遭受了将近一百万人的伤亡，但直到今天仍将保卫朝鲜的胜利视为光荣的胜利。1962 年，解放军袭击了印度军队，表面上是因为他们在喜马拉雅山的中国领土上建立了前哨基地，但实际上是因为中国觉得自己被印度人、美国人、苏联人和中国国民党包围了。中国打印度，用中国古话来说就是“杀鸡儆猴”，以身作则，威慑数个敌人。

Just look at any of the PRC’s wars. In late 1950, waves of Chinese soldiers attacked U.S. forces in Korea for fear that the Americans would conquer North Korea and build military bases there. China suffered almost a million casualties but to this day celebrates its defense of North Korea as a glorious victory. In 1962, the PLA attacked Indian forces, ostensibly because they built outposts in Chinese-claimed territory in the Himalayas, but really because China felt it was being encircled by the Indians, Americans, Soviets, and Chinese Nationalists. By attacking India, China “killed a chicken to scare the monkeys,” as the old Chinese saying goes, coercing several enemies by making an example out of one.

苏联人没有得到这个信息，继续在中国边境集结军队，同时宣称他们有权使用军事力量击退任何社会主义国家的“反革命”，就像他们 1968 年在捷克斯洛伐克所做的那样。由于害怕入侵，中国伏击了苏联军队1969 年在两国共同边界上。十年后，北京再次参战，正如邓小平所说，这一次是为了“给越南上一课”，当时北京与莫斯科签署了防务协议并征服了中国唯一的盟友之一柬埔寨。除了这些战争之外，中国还曾三次（1954-1955 年、1958 年和 1995-1996 年）在台湾领土或附近发射炮弹或导弹，每次都希望阻止台北加强与美国的关系或边缘化走向独立。记录很清楚：当中国感到脆弱时，它就会变得暴力。

The Soviets didn’t get the message and continued to mass forces on China’s borders while asserting their right to use military force to beat back “counterrevolution” in any socialist state, as they did in Czechoslovakia in 1968. Fearing invasion, China ambushed Soviet forces on their shared border in 1969. Ten years later, Beijing again went to war, this time to “teach Vietnam a lesson,” as Deng said, after it signed a defense agreement with Moscow and conquered Cambodia, one of China’s only allies. In addition to these wars, China has launched artillery or missile barrages at or near Taiwanese territory on three occasions (1954–1955, 1958, and 1995–1996), each time hoping to prevent Taipei from tightening its relationship with the United States or edging toward independence. The record is clear: When China feels vulnerable, it gets violent.

今天，有很多鸡可以杀，也有很多可教的时刻可以利用。解放军已于 2020 年在喜马拉雅山与印度发生争执，试图在华盛顿和新德里之间挑拨离间，但未成功。随着印度离美国越来越近，它可能会再次尝试。但是，如果中共真的想击退新兴的反华联盟，就必须打破美国在其沿海地区的联盟和伙伴关系。

Today, there are plenty of chickens to kill and teachable moments to exploit. The PLA already brawled with India in the Himalayas in 2020, seeking—unsuccessfully—to drive a wedge between Washington and New Delhi. It might try again as India draws closer to the United States. But if the CCP really wants to roll back the emerging anti-China coalition, it must break the ring of U.S. alliances and partnerships off its coast.

一个明显的目标是日本。东京是一个可恨的历史敌人目前管理尖阁列岛，中国声称拥有钓鱼岛主权。美日同盟是美国遏制东亚战略的关键。在拉紧与华盛顿的联盟的同时让日本取消钉住汇率制可能会吸引被包围的中国。

An obvious target would be Japan. Tokyo is a hated historical enemy that currently administers the Senkaku Islands, which China claims and calls the Diaoyu Islands. The U.S.-Japan alliance is the linchpin of America’s containment strategy in East Asia. Taking Japan down a peg while straining its alliance with Washington might appeal to an encircled PRC.

中国已经派遣武装海岸警卫队快艇进入钓鱼岛周围的领海，以挑战日本的控制权。中国在升级阶梯上的下一步行动可能是在这些岛屿上登陆士兵；在他们周围宣布一个五十英里的禁区；并用成群结队的舰船、潜艇、战机和无人机包围它们——以中国大陆为基地的导弹作为后盾。届时，日本要么不得不默许中国的吞并，要么就几块布满鸟粪的小岩石与核大国开战。美国将面临同样的困境。它会以经济制裁和无力的外交抗议作为回应吗？还是会兑现 2014 年和 2021 年做出的帮助日本保卫钓鱼岛的承诺？前者的反应可能会破坏美日同盟。根据美国进行的兵棋推演，后一种方法67

China already sends armed coast guard cutters into the territorial waters around the Senkakus to contest Japan’s control. China’s next move up the escalation ladder could be to land soldiers on the islands; declare a fifty-mile exclusion zone around them; and wrap them with swarms of ships, submarines, warplanes, and drones—backed by missiles based on the Chinese mainland. Japan then would either have to acquiesce to China’s annexation or go to war with a nuclear power over a few tiny rocks covered in bird droppings. America would face the same dilemma. Would it respond with economic sanctions and feeble diplomatic protests? Or would it honor the pledges made, in 2014 and again in 2021, to help Japan defend the Senkakus? The former response might wreck the U.S.-Japan alliance. The latter approach, according to wargames conducted by U.S. think-tanks, could end in World War III.67

如果中国不准备与日本这样的地区大国交锋，它可能会在南中国海加强其较弱的海上邻国之一。尽管北京肯定想打倒越南，但菲律宾是一个更有吸引力的目标，它符合完美敌人的所有标准。

If China isn’t ready to rumble with a regional power such as Japan, it could instead muscle one of its weaker maritime neighbors in the South China Sea. Although Beijing would surely like to knock Vietnam down, an even juicier target would be the Philippines, which meets all the criteria of a perfect enemy.

军事薄弱？查看。菲律宾可能正在慢慢转而反对中国，但就目前而言，它的能力很差，北京可以在一次小规模战斗中消灭菲律宾海军和空军。具有象征意义？查看。2016 年，马尼拉将北京告上常设仲裁法庭（又名世界法庭）并胜诉，法庭裁定中国在南中国海的主张无效。作为回应，中国宣布它不会受到半个世界之外的“傀儡”法庭裁决的约束。驱逐菲律宾军队从他们孤立的、无法防御的南中国海前哨基地，或者干脆在北京已经占领但尚未开发的礁石和礁石上建立军事基地，将是中国支持这一宣言的好方法。

Militarily weak? Check. The Philippines may be slowly turning against China, but for now its capabilities are pathetic, and Beijing could wipe out the Filipino navy and air force in a single skirmish. Symbolically important? Check. In 2016, Manila took Beijing to the Permanent Court of Arbitration (aka, the World Court) and won, with the tribunal ruling that China’s South China Sea claims were null and void. China responded by declaring that it would not be bound by the rulings of a “puppet” court half a world away. Ejecting Filipino forces from their isolated, indefensible South China Sea outposts or simply building military bases on rocks and reefs that Beijing has already seized but not yet developed would be a great way for China to back up that declaration.

战略上重要吗？查看。美菲联盟对地区安全至关重要，但自冷战以来就经常摇摇欲坠。尽管华盛顿承诺保卫菲律宾在南中国海的财产，但北京可能不相信。“你会为斯卡伯勒浅滩开战吗？” 2016 年，有人无意中听到参谋长联席会议主席这样说。68如果中国对菲律宾军队大打出手，这将迫使美国做出一个非常艰难的选择：捍卫一个矛盾的盟友的领土主张，或者在中国嘲笑菲律宾时袖手旁观。国际法，扩大对南中国海的控制，并破坏美国在亚洲的联盟承诺的可信度。

Strategically important? Check. The U.S.-Philippines alliance is critical to regional security but has often been shaky since the Cold War. And while Washington has pledged to defend Filipino possessions in the South China Sea, Beijing might not believe it. “Would you go to war over Scarborough Shoals?” the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was overheard saying in 2016.68 If China bludgeoned Filipino forces, it would force the United States into a very tough choice: defend an ambivalent ally over its territorial claims or stand aside as China makes a mockery of international law, expands its control of the South China Sea, and wrecks the credibility of U.S. alliance commitments in Asia.

目标：台湾

TARGET: TAIWAN

尽管这些情况很糟糕，但与可能成为中国复仇运动的主要事件：征服台湾相比，它们就显得苍白无力了。夺取台湾是中国外交政策的首要目标，据报道，收复台湾的准备工作大约消耗了解放军预算的三分之一。69如果中国制服了台湾，它将获得其世界级半导体产业的使用权，并释放出数十艘船只、数百个导弹发射器和战斗机，以及数十亿美元的国防资金，以在更远的地方肆虐。中国可以将台湾作为一艘“不沉的航空母舰”，将力量投射到太平洋，封锁日本和菲律宾，并破坏美国在东亚的联盟。尤其重要的是，成功的侵略将消灭世界上唯一的中国民主，消除对中共合法性的持续威胁。台湾是东亚的重心——也是一个地方的缩影中国领导人可能认为近期的侵略可以从根本上改善他们国家相对于美国的长期轨迹。

As bad as those scenarios are, they pale in comparison to what is likely to be the main event of a Chinese revanchist campaign: the conquest of Taiwan. Grabbing Taiwan is China’s top foreign policy goal, and preparations to reclaim the island reportedly consume roughly one-third of the PLA’s budget.69 If China subdued Taiwan, it would gain access to its world-class semiconductor industry and free up dozens of ships, hundreds of missile launchers and combat aircraft, and billions of defense dollars to wreak havoc farther afield. China could use Taiwan as an “unsinkable aircraft carrier” to project power into the Pacific, blockade Japan and the Philippines, and fracture U.S. alliances in East Asia. Not least, successful aggression would eliminate the world’s only Chinese democracy, removing a persistent threat to the CCP’s legitimacy. Taiwan is the center of gravity in East Asia—and the epitome of a place where China’s leaders might think that near-term aggression could radically improve their country’s long-term trajectory vis-à-vis the United States.

出于其他原因，台湾也是北京最有吸引力的目标。地理不对称是严重的：台湾的防御需要美军在离中国海岸不到 100 英里的地方作战，并从几个脆弱的基地和航空母舰出发数百甚至数千英里。由于其许多部队驻扎在其他地区，美国将一只手绑在背后作战。相比之下，中国可以将大部分军队投入战争，并将其国土作为一个巨大的基地。中国军队将拥有安全的陆基通讯和补给线。他们可以从无数大陆避难所射击、滑行和装弹；整个国家都可以通过住房、食物、供应和运输中国军队来支持战争。

Taiwan is Beijing’s most inviting target for other reasons, as well. The geographic asymmetry is severe: The defense of Taiwan would require U.S. forces to fight less than 100 miles off China’s coast and travel hundreds or even thousands of miles from a few fragile bases and aircraft carriers. With many of its forces stationed in other regions, America would be fighting with one hand tied behind its back. China, by contrast, could throw most of its military into the war and use its homeland as a giant base. Chinese forces would have secure, land-based lines of communications and resupply. They could shoot, scoot, and reload from countless mainland sanctuaries; the entire nation could support the war effort by housing, feeding, supplying, and transporting Chinese troops.

将这些主场优势与中国在东海或南海的战争中所面临的优势进行比较。中国空军和海军部队将不得不在战场和大陆之间飞行数百英里以补充燃料和重新装填，这种通勤将削弱解放军在前线的战斗力，并迫使中国部队依赖易受攻击的通信卫星。中国军队在往返战区的途中每次经过台湾时也必须受到挑战，给解放军的敌人大量的骚扰和消耗机会。

Compare those home-field advantages to what China would face in a war in the East China or South China Seas. Chinese air and naval forces would have to travel hundreds of miles between the battlefield and the mainland to refuel and reload, a commute that would slash PLA combat power on the front lines and force Chinese units to rely on vulnerable communications satellites. Chinese forces would also have to run a gauntlet every time they pass by Taiwan on their way to and from the combat theater, giving the PLA’s foes copious chances for harassment and attrition.

最后，台湾是中国面临其最迅速关闭的机会之窗的地方。和平统一的可能性正在迅速消失：越来越少的台湾人希望成为中国大陆的一部分，而美国正在加强与台北的军事和外交关系。作为回应，中国正在考虑军事选择。

Finally, Taiwan is where China faces its most rapidly closing window of opportunity. The possibility of peaceful reunification is disappearing fast: Fewer and fewer Taiwanese want to be part of mainland China, and the United States is strengthening its military and diplomatic ties with Taipei. In response, China is considering military options.

2020年9月，解放军开始执行最四分之一个世纪以来在台湾海峡咄咄逼人的武力展示。入侵台湾防空识别区的事件激增。中国军事特遣部队大约每隔一天在海峡巡逻一次，其中一些包括 30 多架战斗机和 6 艘海军舰艇。其中许多突破了台湾和中国大陆之间几十年来一直遵守的边界线。其中几次巡逻模拟了对在菲律宾和台湾之间航行的美国航空母舰和驱逐舰的袭击。通过在 2020 年镇压香港的民主运动，中国也表明对台湾进行和平劝说的日子已经结束。

In September 2020, the PLA began carrying out the most aggressive show of force in the Taiwan Strait in a quarter century. Incursions into Taiwan’s air defense identification zone skyrocketed. Chinese military task forces, some involving more than thirty combat aircraft and a half-dozen naval ships, roamed the strait roughly every other day. Many of them breached the median line between Taiwan and China, a boundary that both sides had respected for decades. Several of these patrols simulated attacks on U.S. aircraft carriers and destroyers sailing between the Philippines and Taiwan. By crushing the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong in 2020, China also suggested that the days of peaceful persuasion vis-à-vis Taiwan are finished.

军事攻击能成功吗？直到最近，答案是否定的。在 1990 年代，台湾相对于中国的地理和技术优势使其几乎不可征服。台湾海峡险象环生——台风和 20 英尺巨浪时有发生——而这个岛屿是一座天然堡垒。它的东海岸由陡峭的悬崖组成，其西海岸主要是泥滩，这些泥滩延伸出海面数英里，并受到强烈潮汐的冲击。台湾只有十几个海滩可供入侵部队登陆——美国和台湾的战斗机和海军舰队本可以确保中国军队永远无法靠近。70

Could a military attack succeed? Until recently, the answer was no. In the 1990s, Taiwan’s geographic and technological advantages over China made it virtually unconquerable. The Taiwan Strait is perilous—typhoons and twenty-foot waves are common—and the island is a natural fortress. Its east coast consists of steep cliffs, and its west coast is dominated by mud flats that extend miles out to sea and are buffeted by severe tides. There are only a dozen beaches on Taiwan where an invading force could even land—and U.S. and Taiwanese fighter aircraft and naval armadas could have made sure that China’s army never got close.70

然而，从那以后，中国在国防上的支出比台湾高出 25 比 1。它大量生产了新的军舰、作战飞机和导弹，以及可以运送数千名士兵的两栖舰艇。中国的军队现在是台湾的十倍。中国的远程防空系统可以击落台湾上空的飞机。中国的陆基导弹和战斗机可能会消灭台湾的空军和海军，并摧毁美国在东亚的基地。中国的网络和反卫星能力可能会削弱美军重要的传感器和卫星，从而使他们变得又聋又瞎又哑。中国反舰导弹可以使西太平洋成为一个非常危险的地方适用于任何大型美国水面战舰。四分之一世纪以来，解放军一直专注于准备征服台湾。

Since then, however, China has outspent Taiwan 25-to-1 on defense. It has churned out new warships, combat aircraft, and missiles, along with amphibious craft that can ferry thousands of troops. China’s military is now ten times larger than Taiwan’s. China’s long-range air-defense systems can shoot down aircraft over Taiwan. China’s land-based missiles and combat aircraft could potentially wipe out Taiwan’s air force and navy and destroy U.S. bases in East Asia. China’s cyber and anti-satellite capabilities threaten to render U.S. forces deaf, blind, and dumb by crippling their vital sensors and satellites. Chinese anti-ship missiles can make the western Pacific a very dangerous place for any large U.S. surface combatant. For a quarter-century, the PLA has focused relentlessly on preparing to conquer Taiwan.

相比之下，美军在这一时期的大部分时间都在与中东的恐怖分子作战。最近，它向欧洲输送军队和武器，以支撑北约的东翼。奥巴马、特朗普和拜登政府都希望将美军重心转向亚洲以对抗中国。但这些计划被其他地区发生的事件所取代，包括伊斯兰国的崛起和俄罗斯入侵乌克兰。作为一个全球大国，美国还没有为单一的军事突发事件做准备的奢侈。因此，其空军和海军没有跟上中国军事现代化的步伐。

The U.S. military, by contrast, spent most of this period fighting terrorists in the Middle East. More recently, it has funneled troops and weapons into Europe to shore up NATO’s eastern flank. The Obama, Trump, and Biden administrations all hoped to pivot U.S. forces to Asia to counter China. But those plans were overtaken by events in other regions, including the rise of ISIS and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. As a global power, the United States hasn’t had the luxury of preparing for a single military contingency. Consequently, its air force and navy haven’t kept pace with China’s military modernization.

美国在亚洲的武装力量仍然主要由少量大型军舰和在暴露基地作战的短程作战飞机组成——这正是中国可以在突然的导弹袭击中摧毁的那种力量。美国在台湾 500 英里范围内只有两个空军基地——这是战斗机在耗尽燃料之前可以飞行的最远距离。如果中国禁用这些基地，美军将不得不从航空母舰和距离台湾 1,800 英里的关岛开展行动。额外的距离和空中加油将使美国的空中架次减少一半，让中国有机会主宰台湾上空。更糟糕的是，中国现在拥有轰炸机和弹道导弹，可以打击关岛，并有可能击中距离大陆 1000 多英里以外的移动中​​的航空母舰。71

America’s armed forces in Asia still consist predominantly of small numbers of large warships and short-range combat aircraft operating from exposed bases—precisely the kind of forces China could destroy in a surprise missile attack. The United States only has two air bases within 500 miles of Taiwan—the maximum distance unrefueled fighter aircraft can fly before they run out of gas. If China disables those bases, U.S. forces would have to operate from aircraft carriers and from Guam, located 1,800 miles from Taiwan. The extra distance and midair refueling would cut the number of U.S. air sorties in half, giving China an opportunity to dominate the skies over Taiwan. Worse, China now has bombers and ballistic missiles that can strike Guam and potentially hit moving aircraft carriers more than 1,000 miles from the mainland. If these “Guam-killer” and “carrier-killer” missiles work as advertised, China could cripple U.S. military power in East Asia.71

台湾还没有准备好收拾残局。72作为从应征入伍的军队向更专业的全志愿军过渡的一部分，台湾已将其现役军人从 275,000 人削减至 175,000 人，并将征兵期限从一年缩短至四个月。新兵只接受几周的基础训练，预备役人员很少且不足。台湾还削弱了其后勤部队，后者现在经常无法为作战部队提供补给或进行基本维护。因此，士兵们避免使用武器进行训练，以免发生事故或浪费宝贵的弹药；台湾飞行员每个月的飞行时间不到十个小时。台湾一半以上的坦克和攻击直升机都出现故障，许多台湾士兵士气低落。

Taiwan isn’t ready to pick up the slack.72 As part of its transition from a conscript army to a more professional all-volunteer military, Taiwan has cut its active-duty force from 275,000 to 175,000 troops and reduced the length of conscription from one year to four months. Recruits receive only a few weeks of basic training, and training for reservists is infrequent and inadequate. Taiwan also has gutted its logistics force, which now routinely fails to resupply combat units or perform basic maintenance. Consequently, soldiers avoid training with their weapons for fear of accidents or wasting precious ammunition; Taiwan’s pilots fly for less than ten hours per month. More than half of Taiwan’s tanks and attack helicopters are dysfunctional, and many Taiwanese soldiers suffer low morale.

最重要的是，中国就像 1914 年的德国或 1941 年的日本一样，有一个有利但有限的军事窗口。台湾自己的政府评估说，它可能会“瘫痪”该岛的防御。73正如我们在第 3 章中详述的那样，台湾和美国已经意识到威胁，确定了他们必须解决的关键问题，并开始相应地重组他们的军队。但从现在到 2030 年代初——那时美国和台湾的国防改革将开始产生重大影响——中国有机会。

The bottom line is that China, like Germany in 1914 or Japan in 1941, has a favorable but finite military window. It could, Taiwan’s own government has assessed, “paralyze” the island’s defenses.73 As we detailed in chapter 3, Taiwan and the United States have awoken to the threat, identified the key problems they must solve, and started retooling their militaries accordingly. But between now and the early 2030s—when U.S. and Taiwanese defense reforms will begin to make a major impact—China has its chance.

事实上，到 2020 年代中期，两岸军事平衡将暂时向对中国有利的方向转变，届时许多美国巡洋舰、导弹潜艇和远程轰炸机将退役。74在许多方面，美国军队仍然是罗纳德里根建立的力量。尤其是美国海军和空军的现代化建设已被推迟数十年。现在问题很尖锐。75五角大楼的许多主力舰船和作战飞机实际上正在分崩离析或起火。他们老化的船体和机身无法承受另一次升级，更不用说容纳他们与中国新力量竞争所需的现代发动机、传感器和弹药了。美国的这些能力必须退役。届时，美国军方将减少数百个漂浮在东亚地区的垂直发射导弹管——现代海军火力的必要条件。与此同时，中国将增加数百枚反舰和对地攻击导弹、数十架远程轰炸机和两栖导弹。船只，以及可以从中国大陆打击大部分或整个台湾的火箭发射系统。

In fact, the cross-strait military balance will temporarily shift further in China’s favor in the mid-2020s, when many U.S. cruisers, guided-missile submarines, and long-range bombers will be retired.74 In many ways, the U.S. military is still the force that Ronald Reagan built. U.S. Navy and Air Force modernization, in particular, has been postponed for decades. Now the problem is acute.75 Many of the Pentagon’s workhorse ships and combat aircraft are literally falling apart or bursting into flames. Their aging hulls and airframes can’t withstand another upgrade, let alone accommodate the modern engines, sensors, and munitions they would need to compete with China’s new forces. These U.S. capabilities have to be retired. And when they are, the U.S. military will have hundreds fewer vertical-launch missile tubes—the sine qua non of modern naval firepower—floating around East Asia. Meanwhile, China will bring online hundreds of additional anti-ship and land-attack missiles, dozens of long-range bombers and amphibious ships, and a rocket launcher system that can hit most or all of Taiwan from mainland China.

这在地缘政治上相当于一颗定时炸弹。在 2020 年代中后期，中国再也没有比现在更好的机会打败敌人，满足修正主义的胃口了。正是在这一时期，美国冒着在台湾战争中“被人扔到屁股上”的风险——正如一位前五角大楼官员所说的那样。76

This is the geopolitical equivalent of a ticking time bomb. In the mid to late 2020s, China will never have a better chance to defeat its enemies and satisfy its revisionist appetites. It is during this period that America risks—as one former Pentagon official has said—getting “its ass handed to it” in a Taiwan fight.76

看到这些趋势，一群退役的中国军官和官方新闻媒体正在敦促中共立即入侵台湾。中国公众似乎支持：根据官方媒体《环球时报》 2020 年的一项调查，70% 的大陆人强烈支持使用武力统一台湾，37% 的人认为最好在 2025 年爆发战争. 77闭门造车，中国官员告诉西方分析人士，入侵的呼声在中共内部激增，习近平周围都是鹰派和应声虫，他们告诉他解放军可以成功。78或许正是出于这个原因，习近平将他的合法性押在了解放台湾上。2017年，他宣布统一是“实现中华民族伟大复兴的必然要求”。79 2020 年，中共将其计划部署“现代化”军队的日期从 2034 年提前到 2027年。80 2021 年 3 月，时任印太美军司令的菲利普·戴维森海军上将警告说，中国可能在未来六年内入侵台湾。81

Seeing these trends, a chorus of retired Chinese military officers and state-run news outlets is urging the CCP to invade Taiwan immediately. The Chinese public seems to be aboard: According to a 2020 survey by the state-run Global Times, 70 percent of mainlanders strongly support using force to unify Taiwan with the mainland, and 37 percent think it would be best if the war occurred by 2025.77 Behind closed doors, Chinese officials have told Western analysts that calls for an invasion are proliferating within the CCP, and that Xi is surrounded by hawks and yes-men who tell him that the PLA could pull it off.78 Perhaps for that reason, Xi has staked his legitimacy on liberating Taiwan. In 2017, he announced that reunification is “an inevitable requirement for realizing the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.”79 In 2020, the CCP moved up the date at which it plans to field a “modernized” military from 2034 to 2027.80 In March 2021, Admiral Philip Davidson, then the commander of U.S. forces in the Indo-Pacific, warned that China could invade Taiwan within the next six years.81

中国人有几种选择来挤压台湾并试图使其投降：夺取台北控制但距离中国海岸仅数英里的一个暴露的近海岛屿，实施海上和空中封锁，或者干脆用导弹轰炸台湾。但这些选择会让美国和台湾有时间做出反应，而中国无意给予这一点。他们看到了萨达姆侯赛因的军队是如何在 1990 年至 1991 年的波斯湾战争中被屠杀的，当时五角大楼有数周时间在附近组装一座铁山般的武器并集结一个庞大的国际联盟。他们知道，他们最好的获胜机会是在台湾和美军反击之前，尽早对他们进行猛烈打击。这就是为什么中国的军事学说要求通过珍珠港式的袭击迅速解除对手的武装。82这就是为什么我们应该担心真正可怕的情况。

The Chinese have several options for squeezing Taiwan and trying to make it surrender: Seizing one of the exposed offshore islands controlled by Taipei but located just miles from the Chinese coast, enacting a naval and air blockade, or simply pummeling Taiwan with guided missiles. But these options would give the United States and Taiwan time to react, something the Chinese have no intention of granting. They saw how Saddam Hussein’s forces got massacred in the 1990–1991 Persian Gulf War when the Pentagon had weeks to assemble an iron mountain of weapons nearby and rally a giant international coalition. They know their best chance of winning is to hit Taiwanese and U.S. forces hard and early, before they can fight back. That’s why China’s military doctrine calls for disarming opponents quickly through Pearl Harbor–style attacks.82 And that’s why we should worry about a truly dire scenario.

在最有可能发生的情况下，战争将以数千枚地面和空中发射的中国导弹落在台湾、冲绳和关岛的美国军事基地以及母港在日本的美国航母打击群开始。在台湾各地，卧底的中国特种部队和情报人员会出现，在军事设施引爆炸弹并暗杀台湾领导人。中国的网络攻击将削弱台湾的关键基础设施。解放军还将使用网络攻击，并可能使用地面发射的导弹来摧毁允许美军相互通信以及与华盛顿通信的卫星——从而使美国无法做出反应，甚至无法可靠地知道数天或数周内发生的事情。83解放军的网络部队会同时在美国本土挑起事端，发动虚假宣传活动，在美国制造混乱，加剧政治争端。

In the most likely contingency, the war would start with thousands of ground- and air-launched Chinese missiles raining down on Taiwan, American military bases on Okinawa and Guam, and the U.S. carrier strike group that has its home port in Japan. All over Taiwan, undercover Chinese special forces and intelligence operatives would emerge, detonating bombs at military facilities and assassinating Taiwanese leaders. Chinese cyberattacks would cripple Taiwan’s critical infrastructure. The PLA would also use cyberattacks and, potentially, ground-launched missiles to destroy the satellites that allow U.S. forces to communicate with each other and with Washington—thereby rendering America unable to respond or even reliably know what is happening for days or weeks.83 The PLA’s cyber units would simultaneously stir up trouble on the American home front, unleashing disinformation campaigns to sow confusion and exacerbate political disputes in the United States.

与此同时，此前在台湾海峡进行过军事演习的中国舰队将冲向台湾海滩，而大陆上的数十万中国军队开始涌入舰船和直升机，准备发起主要进攻。小型两栖攻击艇可能会从海峡的民用渡轮中出现，并试图在台湾军队做出反应之前占领一个关键港口或海滩。美国失去了许多前沿部署的在中国突然袭击中，中国军队将不得不从数千英里外调动飞机和军舰，并通过导弹、智能水雷和电磁干扰进行战斗，才能接近台湾。此外，调动这些资产可能需要将它们从其他重要的优先事项上拉开，例如保护北约东部侧翼免受咄咄逼人的俄罗斯的攻击。美国可能会发现自己面临着两个核武器大国的可怕安全挑战——其军队资源只能应对一个。84

Meanwhile, a Chinese flotilla previously engaged in military exercises in the Taiwan Strait would dash for Taiwan’s beaches while hundreds of thousands of Chinese troops on the mainland start piling into ships and helicopters in preparation for the main assault. Small amphibious assault craft could emerge from civilian ferries in the strait and try to seize a key port or beach before Taiwanese forces can respond. The United States, having lost many of its forward-deployed forces in China’s surprise attack, would have to surge aircraft and warships from thousands of miles away and fight through a hail of missiles, smart mines, and electromagnetic interference to get anywhere close to Taiwan. Summoning those assets, moreover, might require wrenching them away from other important priorities, such as protecting NATO’s Eastern flank from an aggressive Russia. The United States might find itself facing dire security challenges against two-nuclear armed great powers—with a military resourced to cope only with one.84

美国将面临痛苦的全球权衡取舍，而太平洋地区的美军将蒙受自越南战争或二战以来前所未有的损失。美国领导人甚至可能发现自己面临一个可怕的两难选择——是接受屈辱性的军事挫折，还是威胁如果中国不让步就使用核武器。一个由国防专家组成的蓝丝带委员会于 2018 年得出结论，美国可能会遭受“决定性的军事失败”，除非它采取有核灾难风险的战略。85地缘政治没有比这更危险的了。

America would confront agonizing global trade-offs, and U.S. forces in the Pacific would incur losses unlike anything since the Vietnam War or possibly World War II. American leaders might even find themselves up against an awful dilemma—whether to accept a humiliating military setback or threaten to use nuclear weapons if China doesn’t stand down. The United States, a blue-ribbon commission of defense experts concluded in 2018, could suffer “a decisive military defeat” unless it resorts to strategies that risk nuclear apocalypse.85 Geopolitics doesn’t get any more dangerous than this.

“可怕的 2020 年代”将是一个糟糕的十年，因为中国已经到了一个糟糕的地缘政治关头——它可以而且必须大胆行动以避免衰落的时刻。86达到顶峰的修正主义者通常会在仍有成功希望的时候寻找机会采取行动。而中国，由于几个近期的机会窗口，看到了诱人的可能性。

The “terrible 2020s” will be a nasty decade because China has reached a nasty geopolitical juncture—the point at which it can and must act boldly to avoid decline.86 A peaking revisionist typically looks for chances to act while it still has some prospect of success. And China, thanks to several near-term windows of opportunity, sees tantalizing possibilities.

大胆与疯狂不同。中国实力趋于平稳，并不意味着它会四面八方猛烈抨击。这确实意味着中国将变得更加强制和咄咄逼人，特别是在它认为现在冒险将创造更好的长期现实的领域。如果中国抢台湾，那么第一岛链就断了，北京的战略地理就改善了极大地。如果中国建立一个高科技帝国，它可能会避免经济停滞和外国包围。如果中共倒退民主，它可以巩固其政权并减少其国际孤立。或许，中国领导人告诉自己，一点点胆量就能让他们摆脱更悲惨的命运。

Boldness isn’t the same thing as insanity. The fact that China’s power has plateaued doesn’t mean that it will lash out violently in all directions. It does mean that China will become more coercive and aggressive, particularly in areas where it thinks risk-taking now will create a better long-term reality. If China grabs Taiwan, then the First Island Chain is broken, and Beijing’s strategic geography improves enormously. If China creates a high-tech empire, it might stave off economic stagnation and foreign encirclement. If the CCP rolls back democracy, it can entrench its regime and reduce its international isolation. Perhaps, China’s leaders tell themselves, a bit of audacity can rescue them from a grimmer fate.

这是一种可能。另一个是这些策略将以悲剧告终。中国的新帝国主义可能会加剧世界各地的冲突。西太平洋的侵略可能导致灾难性升级。达到顶峰的权力不会失去他们的推理能力：1941 年的大多数日本领导人都明白东京很可能会失败。但他们的行为通常会变得更加反复无常，因为他们愿意接受更高的风险来避免可怕的未来。

That’s one possibility. Another is that these gambits will end in tragedy. Chinese neo-imperialism could fuel conflicts around the world. Aggression in the western Pacific could cause cataclysmic escalation. Peaking powers don’t lose their ability to reason: Most Japanese leaders in 1941 understood that Tokyo was likely to lose. But their behavior usually becomes more erratic, because they are willing to accept higher risks to avert a terrifying future.

因此华盛顿有它的工作要做。美国需要一项长期战略来应对一代人或更长时间的独断专制的中国。但它也需要一个短期战略来度过当前十年的高度紧张时期。美国要想和平打赢暮光之战，就必须先穿越危险地带。在这里，历史再次具有指导意义。

Washington thus has its work cut out for it. America needs a long-term strategy for dealing with an assertive, authoritarian China for a generation or more. But it also needs a shorter-term strategy for navigating a period of high tension during the current decade. If the United States is to win the twilight struggle peacefully, it must first traverse the danger zone. Here again, history can be instructive.

6个

6

一场冷战对另一场冷战的启示

What One Cold War Can Teach Us About Another

乔治·凯南 (Gorge Kennan ) 得到报酬以采取长远眼光，但在 1947 年 5 月，他只有最短的时间来做这件事。一年前，这位美国外交官因撰写来自美国驻莫斯科大使馆的著名“长电报”而一举成名。在那份文件中，凯南将苏联描述为正在兴起的冷战中的死敌，同时还指出，优势和劣势的平衡最终将有利于美国。然而，到 1947 年 5 月，凯南担任了国务院政策规划参谋部 (PPS) 主任的新职务——这是一个致力于大局战略的小型精英部门——时间对他和自由世界来说都是一种奢侈。

George Kennan got paid to take the long view, but in May 1947, he had only the shortest window in which to do it. A year earlier, the U.S. diplomat had made a name for himself by authoring his famous “Long Telegram” from America’s embassy in Moscow. In that document, Kennan had described the Soviet Union as an implacable foe in the emerging Cold War, while also arguing that the balance of strengths and weaknesses would favor America in the end. By May 1947, however, Kennan was in a new role as director of the State Department’s Policy Planning Staff (PPS)—its small, elite unit dedicated to big-picture strategy—and time was a luxury neither he nor the free world had.

欧洲正处于生存危机之中。第二次世界大战后，该大陆在经济和政治上仍遭受重创。一个严酷的、破纪录的冬天加剧了苦难。曾经统治世界的大陆现在正处于饥饿、混乱和革命的边缘。用温斯顿·丘吉尔的话说，它已经沦为“瓦砾堆、停尸房、瘟疫和仇恨的温床”。1如果美国不迅速恢复希望和繁荣，那么组织严密的共产党可能会夺取政权或在投票箱中获胜。一旦他们掌权，他们就可以将欧洲大陆交到苏联独裁者约瑟夫·斯大林的手中。“当医生深思熟虑时，病人正在下沉，”国务卿乔治·C·马歇尔——凯南的老板——总结道。需要“毫不拖延”地采取果断行动。2个

Europe was in the grips of an existential crisis. The continent was still devastated, economically and politically, from World War II. A harsh, record-breaking winter had compounded the misery. The continent that had once ruled the world was now on the precipice of starvation, chaos, revolution. It had been reduced, in Winston Churchill’s phrasing, to “a rubble heap, a charnel house, a breeding ground of pestilence and hate.”1 If America didn’t quickly restore hope and prosperity, then well-organized Communist parties might seize power or win it at the ballot box. Once they had power, they could deliver the continent into Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin’s hands. “The patient is sinking while the doctors deliberate,” Secretary of State George C. Marshall—Kennan’s boss—had concluded. Decisive action was needed “without delay.”2

马歇尔给凯南、副国务卿迪安·艾奇逊和其他国务院官员两周的时间来解决这个问题。在三周而不是两周之后出现的可能是美国历史上最著名的外交政策倡议：马歇尔计划。“我们今天能给出的最佳答案，”凯南在一份概述该计划的备忘录中解释说，“也许比一两个月后进行更全面考虑的研究更有用。” 3个马歇尔计划的正式名称是欧洲复苏计划，旨在消除因共产主义接管而软化欧洲大陆的绝望情绪，然后启动持久稳定和强大所需的经济复苏。6 月，马歇尔在哈佛大学的一次演讲中宣布了这个萌芽的想法；夏季和秋季，美国和欧洲官员争先恐后地将模糊的雄心转变为为期四年、价值 130 亿美元的一揽子援助计划，使一个垂死的地区重获生机。最终为美国赢得冷战做出与其他任何政策一样多的政策被匆忙拼凑起来迎接迫不及待的挑战。

Marshall gave Kennan, Under Secretary of State Dean Acheson, and other State Department officials two weeks to solve the problem. What emerged, after three weeks rather than two, was perhaps the most famous foreign policy initiative in American history: The Marshall Plan. “The best answer we can give today,” explained Kennan in a memo outlining the program, “is perhaps more useful than a more thoroughly considered study one or two months hence.”3 Formally known as the European Recovery Program, the Marshall Plan was meant to combat the desperation that was softening up the continent for Communist takeovers, and then to jump-start the economic recovery required for lasting stability and strength. Marshall announced the nascent idea in a speech at Harvard in June; U.S. and European officials scrambled, over the summer and fall, to turn a vague ambition into the four-year, $13 billion aid package that brought a dying region back to life. The policy that ultimately did as much as any other to win the Cold War for America was hastily thrown together to meet a challenge that would not wait.

今天美国面对的中国问题很可怕，但并非前所未有。在早些时候的黄昏斗争中，美国最优秀的战略思想家意识到时间站在自由世界一边——一个病态压抑、经济上不合理的苏联制度将难以永远跟上。然而，在最初的几年里，这是否重要尚不清楚，因为莫斯科有可能在短期内推翻脆弱的全球力量平衡的机会之窗。

The problem America faces vis-à-vis China today is scary, but not unprecedented. During an earlier twilight struggle, America’s best strategic thinkers realized that time was on the free world’s side—that a pathologically repressive, economically irrational Soviet system would struggle to keep up forever. For the first few years, however, it wasn’t clear that this would matter, because Moscow had near-term windows of opportunity in which it might overturn a tenuous global balance of power.

赢得冷战需要跨越一个危险地带，在这个危险地带美国可能很容易输掉这场比赛。同样，它需要利用危机造成的紧迫感采取大胆举措，以在未来几十年加强西方世界。“傻瓜从经验中学习，”俾斯麦说，“聪明人从别人的经验中学习。” 4回顾早期冷战提供的经验教训可以帮助美国制定今天的新危险区战略。

Winning the Cold War required crossing a danger zone in which America might easily have lost that contest instead. No less, it required exploiting the urgency created by crisis to make bold moves that would strengthen the Western world for decades to come. “Fools learn by experience,” Bismarck said, “wise men learn by others’ experience.” 4 Revisiting the early Cold War provides lessons that can help America fashion a new danger-zone strategy today.

冷战危险地带

THE COLD WAR DANGER ZONE

历史类比从来都不是精确的，美中较量不是冷战初期的翻版。2020 年代的中国不是 1940 年代的苏联，即使习近平呈现出明显的斯大林主义倾向。苏联也没有像今天的中国那样处于严重停滞的边缘。5二战结束后，莫斯科期待着急需的经济复苏；红军是打败希特勒并横跨半个欧洲的军事主宰。“俄罗斯将从目前的冲突中脱颖而出，成为迄今为止欧洲和亚洲最强大的国家——强大到足以主宰欧洲，同时确立对亚洲的霸权，”美国情报分析员写道。 1945 年。6

Historical analogies are never exact, and the U.S.-China contest is not a carbon copy of the early Cold War. The China of the 2020s is not the Soviet Union of the 1940s, even if Xi is taking on distinctly Stalinist tendencies. Nor was the Soviet Union on the precipice of severe stagnation, as China is today.5 In the aftermath of World War II, Moscow was looking forward to a much-needed economic recovery; the Red Army was the military juggernaut that had defeated Hitler and marched halfway across Europe. “Russia will emerge from the present conflict as by far the strongest nation in Europe and Asia—strong enough, if the United States should stand aside, to dominate Europe and at the same time to establish her hegemony over Asia,” wrote U.S. intelligence analysts in 1945.6

然而，20 世纪 40 年代后期也呈现出在今天引起共鸣的动态。即使在冷战初期，美国最精明的观察家也意识到，苏联权力的外表比其基础更令人印象深刻。共产主义意识形态、独裁的不安全感和传统的俄罗斯扩张主义的结合意味着克里姆林宫和资本主义世界之间不可能有持久的和解，凯南认为：莫斯科认为“我们社会的内部和谐被破坏是必要的，我们的传统方式生活是如果要确保苏维埃政权的安全，我们国家的国际权威就会被摧毁。” 然而，与西方世界相比，苏联“仍然是较弱的力量”。7

Yet the late 1940s also presented dynamics that resonate today. Even at the dawn of the Cold War, America’s shrewdest observers realized that the façade of Soviet power was more impressive than the foundation. The combination of Communist ideology, autocratic insecurity, and traditional Russian expansionism meant that there could be no lasting accommodation between the Kremlin and the capitalist world, Kennan argued: Moscow deemed it essential “that the internal harmony of our society be disrupted, our traditional way of life be destroyed, the international authority of our state be broken, if Soviet power is to be secure.” Compared to the Western world, however, the Soviets were “still by far the weaker force.”7

凯南相信，莫斯科很难永远统治东欧的被俘民族。恶毒的极权主义政治荒谬和指令经济的内在局限性将严重阻碍苏联在任何长期竞赛中的发展。衰落是不可避免的，凯南在 1947 年指出：苏维埃政权“在其内部承载着自身衰败的种子”，并且“这些种子正在发芽”。美国——一个充满活力的民主国家，占世界产量的近一半——可以“有合理的信心”采取“坚定的遏制政策”，阻止苏联前进，直到衰败从内部摧毁这个体系。8个

Moscow, Kennan believed, would find it hard to dominate captive peoples in Eastern Europe perpetually. The vicious totalitarian absurdities of its politics and the inherent limitations of its command economy would severely handicap the Soviet Union in any long race. Decline was inevitable, Kennan argued in 1947: Soviet power “bears within it the seeds of its own decay” and “the sprouting of those seeds is well advanced.” The United States—a vibrant democracy that accounted for nearly half of world production—could undertake “with reasonable confidence” a “policy of firm containment,” blocking Soviet advances until that decay destroyed the system from within.8

短期内没有信心的理由，因为苏联人没有一个机会之窗，而是两个机会之窗。首先是经济和政治。20 世纪 40 年代后期，世界一片混乱。经济破坏和人类苦难是常态而不是例外：“今天有更多的人因缺乏食物而面临饥饿甚至实际死亡，这比任何战争年份都多，也许比所有战争年份的总和还要多，”总统哈里·杜鲁门 (Harry Truman) 在 1946 年报告说9这场战争造成了权力真空，并引发了从西欧到东南亚的政治激进主义；忠于莫斯科的共产党因信仰的新信徒而膨胀。“我们所知道的生活方式，”马歇尔会说，“实际上是平衡的。” 10如果苏联或其代理人能够利用这一混乱局面夺取对关键国家的政治控制权，斯大林可能会不费一枪一弹就主宰欧亚大陆的大部分地区。

There was less cause for confidence in the near term, because the Soviets had not one but two windows of opportunity. The first was economic and political. The world was in chaos in the late 1940s. Economic devastation and human misery were the rule rather than the exception: “More people face starvation and even actual death for want of food today than in any war year and perhaps more than in all the war years combined,” President Harry Truman reported in 1946.9 The war had created power vacuums and sparked political radicalism from Western Europe to Southeast Asia; Communist parties loyal to Moscow were swelling with new adherents to the faith. “The way of life we have known,” Marshall would remark, “is literally in balance.”10 If the Soviet Union or its proxies could exploit this chaos to grab political control of key countries, Stalin might dominate much of Eurasia without firing a shot.

第二个窗口是军事性质的。到 1947 年，美国已将 1945 年约 1200 万的战斗力削减到不到 200 万。它的整体军事潜力仍然很大比苏联强，但它现有的军事力量已经消失了。虽然华盛顿在原子弹方面有保险政策，但它并没有足够的这些武器来阻止苏联对西欧、中东或东西方分界线的任何其他热点地区的进攻。苏联人在 1949 年制造出自己的原子弹后，美国就失去了这张王牌——五角大楼的策划者担心它很可能会输掉一场全球战争。11即使没有出现这种可怕的情况，军事力量的失衡也可能让莫斯科通过欺凌和恐吓扩大其影响力：“苏联武装力量的阴影”，凯南承认，可能对自由世界“产生瘫痪作用”。12

The second window was of a military nature. The United States had cut a fighting force of some 12 million men in 1945 to one of well under 2 million by 1947. Its overall military potential was still vastly greater than that of the Soviet Union, but its existing military power had melted away. And while Washington had an insurance policy in the atomic bomb, it didn’t have nearly enough of those weapons to stop a Soviet offensive into Western Europe, the Middle East, or any other hot spot along the East-West divide. Once the Soviets built their own atomic bomb in 1949, America had lost this trump card—and Pentagon planners worried that it might well lose a global war.11 Even short of that horrifying scenario, an imbalance of military power might let Moscow expand its influence through bullying and intimidation: “The shadow of Soviet armed strength,” Kennan acknowledged, could “have a paralyzing effect” on the free world.12

因此，杜鲁门时代是一个持续不安全的时期。有多次战争恐慌：1946 年在土耳其摊牌期间，1948 年共产党军队在捷克斯洛伐克夺取政权之后，以及斯大林当年晚些时候封锁了分裂的柏林西部地区之后。苏联的代理人朝鲜确实在 1950 年试图征服韩国而引发了一场重大冲突。“看起来第三次世界大战就在这里，”杜鲁门写道。13军事平衡也发生了深刻而令人不安的变化，尤其是在美国失去原子垄断地位并不得不面对其明显的常规劣势之后。最重要的是，人们普遍认为，美国必须经受迫在眉睫的威胁的挑战，才能进入更长期的冷战，在冷战中，美国的经济和政治优势可能具有决定性意义。“一般来说 。. . 时间站在我们这边，”参谋长联席会议在 1951 年写道。但“关键时期”将是“未来两三年”。14

The Truman years were, consequently, a period of unrelenting insecurity. There were multiple war scares: During a showdown over Turkey in 1946, after Communist forces seized power in Czechoslovakia in 1948, and after Stalin blockaded the western sectors of a divided Berlin later that year. A Soviet proxy, North Korea, did start a major conflict by trying to conquer South Korea in 1950. “It looks like World War III is here,” Truman wrote.13 There were also profound, disconcerting shifts in the military balance, particularly after the United States lost its atomic monopoly and had to face its glaring conventional inferiority. Most of all, there was a pervasive sense that America must run a gauntlet of imminent threats just to reach a longer Cold War in which its economic and political advantages might be decisive. “In general . . . time is on our side,” wrote the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1951. But “the critical period” would be “the next two or three years.”14

美国将度过这个关键时期。杜鲁门政府奉行具有里程碑意义的政策，帮助美国在短期内避免失败，同时为长期的胜利做好准备——尽管它也遭受了严重的挫折并犯下了明显的错误。援助希腊和土耳其的杜鲁门主义1947 年巩固了通往两大洲门户的濒临灭绝的前哨站，同时明确表示美国将抵制共产主义扩张。马歇尔计划和北约的成立将欧洲从令人担忧的弱点变成了西方力量的支柱。日本和西德的复兴将最近的敌人变成了美国最好的盟友；柏林空运使另一个伟大的欧洲城市免于完全滑入铁幕。美国对朝鲜的干预阻止了世界心理力量平衡的崩溃，而随后美国军事实力的增强在关键时刻加强了物理平衡。其他倡议，有些著名，有些现在已被遗忘，使美国得以在冷战初期幸存下来，并在随后的长期斗争中蓬勃发展。

The United States would make it through this critical period. The Truman administration pursued landmark policies that helped America avoid defeat in the near term while positioning it for victory in the long term—even as it also suffered severe setbacks and made glaring mistakes. The Truman Doctrine of aid to Greece and Turkey in 1947 shored up endangered outposts at the gateway to two continents while making clear that America would resist Communist expansion. The Marshall Plan and the creation of NATO changed Europe from a source of alarming weakness to a pillar of Western strength. The revival of Japan and West Germany turned recent enemies into some of America’s best allies; the Berlin airlift kept another great European city from slipping entirely behind the Iron Curtain. The U.S. intervention in Korea prevented a collapse of the world’s psychological balance of power, while the subsequent buildup of American military strength reinforced the physical balance at a crucial time. Other initiatives, some famous and some now forgotten, allowed America to survive the early Cold War and thrive in the protracted struggle that followed.

“当历史说我的任期见证了冷战的开始，”杜鲁门在 1953 年退休时可以吹嘘说，“它也会说，在这 8 年里，我们已经确定了我们能够赢得冷战的方向。” 15事实上，早期的冷战也许是成功的危险地带战略的最佳历史范例。美国当年奉行的具体政策，现在不能简单复制。但美国的经验确实揭示了关于跨越危险区域需要什么的四个战略见解。

“When history says that my term of office saw the beginning of the cold war,” Truman could brag as he retired in 1953, “it will also say that in those 8 years we have set the course that we can win it.”15 Indeed, the early Cold War is perhaps the best historical example of a successful danger-zone strategy. The specific policies America followed back then can’t simply be replicated now. But America’s experience does reveal four strategic insights about what crossing a danger zone requires.

要事第一

FIRST THINGS FIRST

首先，无情地确定优先次序。清楚地考虑在哪里下大赌注以及在哪里节约资源始终很重要；当威胁程度高而错误余地低时，这可能是生死攸关的问题。关键是要防止可能显着改变长期力量平衡的短期突破，并进行早期投资以创造持久的实力。美国在冷战初期基本上遵守了这一规则，尽管这样做比看起来要难。

First, prioritize ruthlessly. Thinking clearly about where to bet big and where to conserve resources is always important; it can be a matter of life and death when the level of threat is high and the margin for error is low. The key is to prevent near-term breakthroughs that can dramatically shift the longer-term balance of power—and to make early investments that create lasting legacies of strength. The United States mostly obeyed this rule during the early Cold War, although doing so was harder than it seemed.

和现在一样，当时的基本问题是美国几乎处处都面临着压力。1946 年至 1947 年，杜鲁门政府面临着从欧洲大西洋沿岸一直延伸到太平洋的不稳定弧形危机。在法国和意大利、希腊和土耳其、伊朗和印度尼西亚、中国和韩国以及其他地方，共产主义的进步似乎是可能的，甚至是有可能的。问题是华盛顿将如何回应。

The basic problem, then as now, was that America was under pressure almost everywhere. In 1946–1947, the Truman administration faced crises along an arc of instability running from the Atlantic coast of Europe all the way to the Pacific. Communist advances seemed possible, even likely, in France and Italy, Greece and Turkey, Iran and Indonesia, China and Korea, and other locales. The question was how Washington would respond.

杜鲁门在 1947 年 3 月给出了一个答案，当时他前往国会请求向希腊和土耳其提供大约 4 亿美元的紧急援助，前者受到共产主义叛乱的威胁，后者面临苏联的领土要求和军事胁迫。“在世界历史的当前时刻，几乎每个国家都必须在不同的生活方式之间做出选择，”杜鲁门宣称。美国必须“支持抵抗武装少数或外部压力企图征服的自由人民”。16

Truman gave one answer in March 1947, when he went before Congress to request roughly $400 million in emergency aid for Greece and Turkey, the former menaced by a Communist insurgency and the latter facing Soviet territorial demands and military coercion. “At the present moment in world history nearly every nation must choose between alternative ways of life,” Truman declared. The United States must “support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or by outside pressures.”16

严厉的措辞是故意的。“这是美国对共产主义暴政扩张浪潮的回应，”杜鲁门后来写道。“它必须清晰明了，没有犹豫或双关语。” 17美国必须通过生动地解释冷战中的利害关系来争取国内对遏制的支持；它必须表明美国将与抵抗极权主义侵略的国家站在一起。但杜鲁门的信息暗示美国将对共产党在各地的调查做出同样的反应，而总统很快意识到这是不可能的。“我们的资源不是无限的，”他承认。拒绝在任何地方节约将导致无处不在。18

The stark phrasing was deliberate. “This was America’s answer to the surge of expansion of Communist tyranny,” Truman later wrote. “It had to be clear and free of hesitation or double talk.”17 The United States must rally domestic support for containment by vividly explaining what was at stake in the Cold War; it must signal that America would stand with countries resisting totalitarian aggression. But the implication of Truman’s message was that America would respond equally to Communist probes everywhere, and the president soon realized this was impossible. “Our resources are not unlimited,” he admitted. A refusal to economize anywhere would lead to weakness everywhere.18

杜鲁门的团队在 1947 年的大部分时间里都在讨论竞争的哪些战场是真正重要的——哪些战场上的直接挫折可能会给莫斯科带来持久的优势，而今天的胜利可能会给西方带来持久的优势。重要地点是日本，尤其是西欧。如果这两个工业中心可能落入苏联控制，整个全球平衡可能会向斯大林有利。如果他们能够复活并与非共产主义世界联系在一起，克里姆林宫将面临严重的、可能无法克服的赤字。“这意味着世界和平，如果我们能够在欧洲实现复苏，”杜鲁门评论道：该地区是冷战的重心。19

Truman’s team spent much of 1947 hashing out which theaters of the competition were truly vital—where immediate setbacks might give Moscow a lasting advantage, and where wins today might give the West an enduring edge. The vital sites were Japan and, especially, Western Europe. If these two centers of industrial might fell under Soviet control, the entire global balance might tip in Stalin’s favor. If they could be revived and tied to the non-Communist world, the Kremlin would be at a grave, possibly insurmountable, deficit. “That means peace in the world, if we can get recovery in Europe,” Truman commented: The region was the center of gravity in the Cold War.19

西欧和日本在另一个方面至关重要：它们是最能凸显美苏目标不对称的地区。莫斯科要想占上风，就必须控制大多数人希望摆脱共产主义统治的国家。美国要想保住自己的地位，就必须拒绝苏联的控制。正如凯南所说，华盛顿可以与“当地抵抗力量”合作以维持他们的独立，而苏联则必须与他们对抗才能将其扼杀。20这种动力为美国创造了巨大的力量倍增器——一种利用自由、友好国家的努力的能力——这是苏联从未享受过的。

Western Europe and Japan were crucial in another respect: They were the areas that most highlighted the asymmetry of U.S. and Soviet aims. For Moscow to gain the upper hand, it would have to control countries where most people preferred to remain free of Communist domination. For the United States to preserve its position, it had only to deny the Soviets that control. Washington could work with “local forces of resistance” to maintain their independence, as Kennan put it, whereas the Soviets had to work against them to snuff it out.20 This dynamic created a tremendous force-multiplier for America—an ability to capitalize on the exertions of free, friendly nations—that the Soviets never enjoyed.

20 世纪 40 年代后期见证了对承诺的残酷分类。美国向西欧和日本提供了创纪录数量的援助——相当于 1948 年美国国民生产总值的 5%。21华盛顿由此开始了将东京变成太平洋反共堡垒的进程。与此同时，美国官员明确表示，他们愿意不惜一切代价——无论是公布马歇尔计划，还是打破 150 年的外交先例，建立和平时期的军事联盟——北约——来保护西欧。“如果西欧发生任何事情，”艾奇逊在取代马歇尔担任国务卿后评论道，“整个企业都会崩溃。” 22美国的承诺不会有任何不确定性：苏联对西欧的任何攻击都意味着与美国的全面冲突。23

The late 1940s saw a brutal sorting of commitments. The United States poured historic amounts of aid—equal to 5 percent of U.S. gross national product in 1948—into Western Europe and Japan.21 Washington thereby began the process of turning Tokyo into an anti-Communist bastion in the Pacific. Meanwhile, American officials made clear that they were willing to go to nearly any length—whether by unveiling the Marshall Plan or breaking with 150 years of diplomatic precedent by establishing a peacetime military alliance, NATO—to protect Western Europe. “If anything happens in Western Europe,” Acheson would comment after replacing Marshall as secretary of state, “the whole business goes to pieces.”22 There would be no uncertainty about the U.S. commitment: Any Soviet attack on Western Europe would mean all-out conflict with the United States.23

与此同时，杜鲁门选择不全力以赴努力阻止共产党在被认为不那么重要或不太有希望的地方取得胜利。一个恰当的例子：华盛顿并没有阻止毛泽东的共产党人打败蒋介石的国民党，其假设是一个不发达、贫困的中国在全球力量的规模上并不重要。杜鲁门还从韩国撤军，当时韩国是一个不稳定、贫穷的国家。艾奇逊公开宣布，该国位于美国在太平洋的防御范围之外。在外围地区不全力以赴是在冷战核心地区发挥作用的代价。24

At the same time, Truman opted not to make an all-out effort to prevent Communist victories in places considered less important or promising. Case in point: Washington did little to prevent Mao’s Communists from defeating Chiang’s Nationalists, on the assumption that an underdeveloped, poverty-stricken China didn’t weigh heavily on the scales of global power. Truman also withdrew U.S. forces from South Korea, then an unstable, impoverished nation; Acheson publicly announced that the country was outside America’s defense perimeter in the Pacific. Not going all-out in peripheral areas was the cost of being effective at the core of the Cold War.24

区分重要区域和次要区域并不总是那么容易。如果不确保中东的石油掌握在友好的手中，美国就无法重建欧洲——或者如果不保护其进入印度支那等地的市场和资源，美国就无法重建日本。25中国在 1949 年落入毛泽东的手下，对美国来说可能不是一场战略灾难，但对杜鲁门来说却是一场政治灾难，杜鲁门后来变得不太愿意取消在亚洲其他暴露的地位。反过来，这种不情愿导致美国的承诺逐渐扩大，并导致美国走上通往越南悲剧的漫长道路。

It wasn’t always easy to distinguish between vital and secondary areas. America could not rebuild Europe without ensuring that Middle Eastern oil remained in friendly hands—or rebuild Japan without protecting its access to markets and resources in places such as Indochina.25 The fall of China to Mao’s forces in 1949 may not have been a strategic disaster for America, but it was a political disaster for Truman, who then became less willing to write off other exposed positions in Asia. That reluctance, in turn, led to a gradual expansion of U.S. commitments and led America down a long road to tragedy in Vietnam.

一个更紧迫的问题是，宣布美国不会捍卫的东西可能会诱使敌人向那里推进——而且当他们受到攻击时，非重要的利益可能会突然变得重要。这就是韩国发生的事情。艾奇逊在 1950 年 1 月宣布韩国独立，这有助于说服投机取巧的斯大林在 6 月批准朝鲜入侵。出乎斯大林意料的是，杜鲁门随即决定参战。他这样做并不是因为韩国本身极其重要（事实并非如此），而是因为未能阻止那里的公然侵略可能会粉碎华盛顿试图在更重要领域建立的信心。“你可以肯定，所有欧洲人都在关注美国将采取的行动，更不用说亚洲人了，”一位国务院官员说。写道：如果斯大林的爪牙简单地破坏心理平衡，美国就很难建立稳定的地缘政治平衡。26

A more immediate problem was that announcing what the United States would not defend could entice enemies to advance there—and that nonvital interests could suddenly become vital when they were attacked. This is what happened in Korea. Acheson’s declaration that South Korea was on its own in January 1950 helped persuade an opportunistic Stalin to approve the North Korean invasion in June. To Stalin’s surprise, Truman then decided to enter the fray. He did so not because South Korea itself was vitally important (it wasn’t), but because a failure to thwart blatant aggression there might shatter the confidence Washington was seeking to build in more important areas. “You may be sure that all Europeans to say nothing of the Asiatics are watching to see what the United States will do,” one State Department official wrote: The United States could hardly build a stable geopolitical balance if Stalin’s minions simply destroyed the psychological balance.26

杜鲁门干预的决定是正确的：它使韩国免于毁灭，并让焦虑的盟友放心，西方不会进入另一个绥靖时代。“感谢上帝，这不会是过去的重演，”法国外交部长惊呼道。27不幸的是，它也让美国不得不在战略死水区打一场血腥的、耗尽精力的冲突——当美国在 1950 年底试图重新统一整个半岛但未能成功时，这场冲突将急剧升级。

Truman’s decision to intervene was the right one: It saved South Korea from destruction and reassured anxious allies that the West was not entering another age of appeasement. “Thank God this will not be a repetition of the past,” the French foreign minister exclaimed.27 Unfortunately, it also consigned the United States to fighting a bloody, draining conflict in a strategic backwater—a conflict that would escalate dramatically when the United States tried and failed to reunite the entire peninsula in late 1950.

不过，在大多数情况下，政府一直在关注这个问题。杜鲁门和艾奇逊利用偏远战争培养的紧迫感来巩固美国在更关键战区的地位：在朝鲜战争最激烈的时候，美国向西欧和西欧增派了四个师的部队与日本缔结了和平条约和安全条约。艾奇逊解释说，那个国家是“整个远东局势的核心”。28正如韩国所表明的那样，一个超级大国永远不可能只专注于一个问题：有时敌人会做出令人震惊和厚颜无耻的事情，以至于需要在意想不到的地方采取行动。但要穿越危险地带，需要优先考虑弱点的短期后果可能是灾难性的领域——而实力的长期好处可能是变革性的。

For the most part, though, the administration kept its eye on the ball. Truman and Acheson used the sense of emergency fostered by an out-of-the-way war to fortify America’s position in more crucial theaters: At the height of the fighting in Korea, the United States dispatched four additional divisions of troops to Western Europe and concluded a peace treaty and security pact with Japan. That country, Acheson explained, was “the heart of the whole Far Eastern situation.”28 As Korea showed, a superpower can never concentrate on just one problem: Sometimes an enemy does something so shocking and brazen that it demands action in an unexpected place. But getting through a danger zone requires prioritizing areas where the near-term consequences of weakness could be catastrophic—and the long-term benefits of strength can be transformative.

马虎的;粗陋的

ROUGH AND READY

第二，将战略目的与战术敏捷相结合。高度紧张的时期不是漫无目的地游荡的时候，但也不是死板教条的时候。当陷入危险地带时，一个国家需要明确、明确的目标，以及一个粗略的准备实现它们的方法。它应该充分利用当今可用的足够好的解决方案和朋友，而不是等待可能为时已晚的理想解决方案。

Second, combine strategic purpose with tactical agility. A period of high tensions is no time to be wandering without aim, but neither is it a time to be rigid and dogmatic. When caught in the danger zone, a country needs clear, well-articulated objectives, as well as a rough-and-ready approach to achieving them. It should make the most of good-enough solutions—and friends—that are available today, rather than waiting for ideal ones that may not come along until too late.

凯南很清楚这一点。PPS 主管是 20 世纪 40 年代后期大规模战略规划工作的核心。Kennan 的 PPS 负责整理优先级并定义长期目标。参谋长联席会议进行了详细研究，以确定哪些领域对美国安全最重要。从这一切中出现了一个清晰、优雅的战略概念：美国将牵制苏联，直到它的内部弱点将其击垮，它主要通过在克里姆林宫的欧亚侧翼建立西方力量的阵地来实现这一目标。马歇尔说，美国的目标是“恢复欧洲和亚洲的力量平衡”，“所有行动”都应从这个角度来看待。29

Kennan knew this well. The PPS director was at the center of a massive strategic planning effort in the late 1940s. Kennan’s PPS was charged with sorting out priorities and defining long-range goals. The Joint Chiefs of Staff conducted detailed studies to determine which areas were most important to American security. From all this emerged a clear, elegant strategic concept: America would hold the Soviet Union in check until its internal weakness brought it down, and it would do so primarily by building positions of Western strength along the Kremlin’s Eurasian flanks. America’s goal, stated Marshall, was “the restoration of balance of power in both Europe and Asia,” and “all actions” would be viewed in this light.29

然而，凯南也意识到，要想在激烈的竞争中保持领先地位，就需要灵巧。在掌管 PPS 仅数周后，他就已经得出结论，不可能对大量问题给出完美的答案。他说：“我们希望解决这些问题的唯一方法是，如果我们能够说服世界在我们坐下来仔细考虑的同时停滞六个月。” “但生活不会停滞不前，由此产生的混乱是可怕的。” 30

Yet Kennan also realized that dexterity would be required to stay on top of a dynamic rivalry. Just weeks after taking charge at the PPS, he had already concluded that it was impossible to come up with perfect answers to an avalanche of problems. “The only way we could ever hope to solve them would be if we could persuade the world to stand still for six months while we sit down and think it over,” he said. “But life does not stand still, and the resulting confusion is terrific.”30

这对美国政策意味着什么？一方面，速度非常重要：美国官员快速推进重大举措。杜鲁门主义涉及一项历史性决定，即援助希腊和土耳其，并让美国承诺支持濒临灭绝的世界。更值得注意的是，杜鲁门的助手在几天内起草了该计划的初步大纲，然后在英国官员周五下午通过通知国务院宣布破产伦敦让雅典和安卡拉听天由命。这正如一位英国外交官所写，政府立即意识到，“不能浪费时间从我们冰冷的手中夺走世界领导权的火炬。” 31

What did this mean for U.S. policy? For one thing, speed was at a premium: American officials fast-tracked big initiatives. The Truman Doctrine involved a historic decision to aid Greece and Turkey and commit the United States to shoring up an endangered world. Which made it all the more noteworthy that Truman’s aides drew up the initial outlines of the plan in a few days, and then worked out the details over three hectic weeks, after British officials dropped a Friday afternoon bombshell by informing the State Department that a bankrupt London was leaving Athens and Ankara to their fate. The administration instantly grasped, as one British diplomat wrote, that “no time must be lost in plucking the torch of world leadership from our chilling hands.”31

美国官员还必须发挥手头的创意。1948 年初，意大利的前途未卜：共产主义有可能在选举中获胜。作为回应，中央情报局、国务院和其他机构发起了一场“除了厨房水槽之外的一切”运动，以阻止意大利人投票让他们的国家进入极权主义。华盛顿向受宠的政客提供了成袋的现金。国务院策划了一场由意大利裔美国人写信给他们在祖国的家人的活动。美国使用新闻片、邮票和祈祷卡作为反共宣传的工具。美国官员甚至安排了一次具有战略意义的英国煤炭运输，以帮助阻止经济和政治灾难。“美国的一举一动都将直接影响结果，”美国32

American officials also had to get creative with the tools at hand. In early 1948, Italy’s future hung in the balance: A Communist electoral victory was a real possibility. In response, the CIA, the State Department, and other agencies mounted an everything-but-the-kitchen-sink campaign to keep Italians from voting their country into totalitarianism. Washington delivered bags of cash to favored politicians. The State Department orchestrated a letter-writing campaign by Italian-Americans to their families in the old country. The United States used newsreels, stamps, and prayer cards as vehicles for anti-Communist propaganda. American officials even arranged a strategically timed shipment of British coal to help head off economic and political disaster. “Every action of the U.S. will have a direct bearing on the outcome,” the U.S. ambassador wrote—so Washington must make the most of whatever weapons it had available.32

组建自由世界联盟也是如此。杜鲁门可能将冷战称为民主与极权主义之间的较量，但他在围捕反苏队伍时从未让完美成为善良的敌人。在 20 世纪 40 年代后期，美国迅速从对日本和德国——这两个刚刚恐吓世界的国家——的惩罚性军事占领转向将它们重建为冷战盟友的计划。1945 年，美国轰炸机摧毁了柏林；1948 年，他们通过盟军空运使其公民得以存活。杜鲁门甚至用优秀的共产党人来制衡坏人：在斯大林于 1948 年与南斯拉夫发生激烈争执后，华盛顿将这个共产主义国家列为默契盟友。

The same went for assembling the free-world coalition. Truman may have labeled the Cold War a contest between democracy and totalitarianism, but he never let the perfect be the enemy of the good in rounding up an anti-Soviet posse. In the late 1940s, America quickly pivoted from punitive military occupations of Japan and Germany—the countries that had just terrorized the world—to programs that rebuilt them as Cold War allies. In 1945, U.S. bombers had pulverized Berlin; in 1948, they kept its citizens alive through the allied airlift. Truman even used good Communists to check bad ones: After Stalin had a venomous falling out with Yugoslavia in 1948, Washington enlisted that Communist country as a tacit ally.

尤其重要的是，穿越危险地带需要为了创新而牺牲传统。最好的例子是离开如此激进，甚至连凯南都反对——北约的创立。该联盟是一个战略分水岭：它在美国宪法程序允许的范围内明确表明美国完全致力于西欧的自由。33然而，北约并不是美国任何宏伟计划的一部分。

Not least, getting through the danger zone required sacrificing tradition for the sake of innovation. The best example of this was a departure so radical that it was opposed even by Kennan—the creation of NATO. That alliance was a strategic watershed: It signaled, as unambiguously as America’s constitutional processes allowed, that the United States was fully committed to the freedom of Western Europe.33 NATO was not, however, part of any grand American plan.

直到 1948 年初，杜鲁门政府还无意建立一个“纠缠不清的”和平时期联盟。北约是欧洲强加给美国官员的想法。这也是对快速爆发的危机——即 1948 年 2 月的捷克政变和 6 月的柏林封锁——的疯狂反应，这让欧洲人感到恐惧，并使杜鲁门政府相信，除了正式的防御条约之外，没有什么能使他们抵抗苏联的压力. 苏联人变得更加咄咄逼人。战争的可能性正在上升。只有采取前所未有的措施，美国才能坚守阵地。欧洲人“'完全失去了皮肤，坐立不安'，必须尽快在他们心中重新创造希望，”马歇尔说。34

As late as early 1948, the Truman administration had no intention of creating an “entangling” peacetime alliance. NATO was a European idea pressed upon U.S. officials. It was also a frantic response to fast-breaking crises—namely the Czech coup in February 1948 and the Berlin blockade in June—that terrified the Europeans and convinced the Truman administration that nothing short of a formal defense treaty could buck them up against Soviet pressure. The Soviets were becoming more aggressive; the chances of war were rising. Only through unprecedented steps could America hold the line. The Europeans were “ ‘completely out of their skin, and sitting on their nerves,’ and hope must be recreated in them very soon,” Marshall said.34

重新创造希望需要克服美国战略遗产中最令人尊敬的方面之一——正如一位孤立主义参议员曾经说过的那样，“我们希望美国为美国人，欧洲为欧洲人，这是一个很好的美国信条。 ” 35在接下来的几年里，还需要狂热地工作，将北约从一个主要存在于纸面上的联盟转变为一个可以认真打击苏联侵略的军事联盟。美国在 20 世纪 40 年代后期普遍知道它想要什么——一个稳定、安全的西欧——但必须灵活地弄清楚如何实现它。

Re-creating that hope required overcoming one of the most venerable aspects of America’s strategic heritage—the idea, as an isolationist senator had once put it, that “we want America for Americans and Europe for Europeans, and that is a good American doctrine.”35 It would also require working feverishly, in the years that followed, to change NATO from an alliance that existed mostly on paper to a military coalition that could put up a serious fight against Soviet aggression. The United States generally knew what it wanted in the late 1940s—a stable, secure Western Europe—but had to be flexible in figuring out how to get it.

美国官员并没有随波逐流。然而，最重要的倡议，如北约，往往是针对迫在眉睫的问题的临时解决方案。美国使用了它所拥有的工具来防止不稳定的局势完全崩溃。它依赖于在不寻常的情况下聚集在一起的新的、有时是杂乱无章的团队。它以紧迫感和适应性来应对紧迫的威胁。如果说杜鲁门时代现在被视为政策创新的黄金时代，那是因为华盛顿深思熟虑——而且行动迅速。

American officials weren’t just making things up as they went along. Yet the most important initiatives, such as NATO, were often improvised solutions to imminent problems. The United States used the tools it had to prevent an unstable situation from collapsing entirely. It relied on new and sometimes motley crews that came together in unusual circumstances. It moved with urgency and adaptability in meeting pressing threats. If the Truman years are now remembered as a golden age of policy innovation, it was because Washington thought deliberately—and acted quickly.

冒险生意

RISKY BUSINESS

第三，少许进攻是最好的防守。危险地带战略包括通过探查敌人的弱点或使其失去平衡来与敌人作战。他们需要大胆的措施来关闭潜在的致命漏洞。但每一步都必须慎重，因为粗心大意的挑衅可能是致命的。关键是要有计划地承担风险——避免鲁莽的风险，因为这些风险会让竞争对手相信，除了孤注一掷之外别无更好的选择。

Third, a little offense is the best defense. Danger-zone strategies involve taking the fight to the enemy by probing its weaknesses or throwing it off-balance. They require bold measures to close off potentially fatal vulnerabilities. But every step must be measured, because heedless provocation can be deadly. The key is to take calculated risks—and avoid reckless ones that convince a rival it has no better option than to go for broke.

这种经过深思熟虑的冒险精神融入了美国的政策，因为保护自由世界的唯一方法就是采取行动对抗强大的敌人。36启动马歇尔计划意味着将阻挠主义的、第五纵队的共产党部长踢出西欧政府，从而招致激进左派的愤怒——以罢工、暴动和暴力的形式。在斯大林切断通往这座孤立城市的地面和铁路通道后，进行柏林空运意味着赌苏联人不会击落美国飞机或利用西方的军事弱点。杜鲁门政府正确地决定，这些风险是值得冒的，因为事实证明，弱点比强势更具挑衅性，而且美国情报分析人士怀疑莫斯科在从二战中恢复过来之前会发动第三次世界大战。37但这一经验凸显了危险区域战略的内在困境：没有完全安全的行动方案。

This calculated risk-taking infused U.S. policy, because the only way to protect the free world was to make moves that antagonized powerful enemies.36 Launching the Marshall Plan meant kicking obstructionist, fifth-column Communist ministers out of Western European governments, and thereby incurring the wrath—in the form of strikes, riots, and violence—of the radical Left. Undertaking the Berlin airlift, after Stalin cut off ground and rail access to that isolated city, meant gambling that the Soviets would not shoot down American planes or take advantage of the West’s military weakness. The Truman administration decided, correctly, that these risks were worth running, because weakness could prove more provocative than strength, and because U.S. intelligence analysts doubted that Moscow would start World War III until it had recovered from World War II.37 But the experience underscored an inherent dilemma of danger-zone strategy: There is no entirely safe course of action.

这就是为什么美国做了一些更具前瞻性的事情：它试图破坏苏联集团，尽管是谦虚的。在冷战初期，美国官员认为，为巩固西方阵地而进行的艰苦努力必须与有选择地削弱苏联阵地的努力相结合。凯南解释说，美国的政策涉及“将我们自己的世界团结在一起”和“增加苏联世界的破坏性压力”。38

This was why the United States did something even more forward-leaning: It tried, albeit modestly, to undermine the Soviet bloc. In the early days of the Cold War, American officials believed that harried efforts to shore up Western positions had to be paired with selective efforts to weaken Soviet positions. U.S. policy, explained Kennan, involved “holding our own world together” and “increasing the disruptive strains in the Soviet world.”38

为此，美国最初向东欧和西欧提供马歇尔计划援助——其计算是，高度怀疑的莫斯科将迫使卫星国家衰落，从而摧毁其自身在集团中的道德权威。华盛顿随后向东欧发射无线电广播，渲染苏联支持政权的罪行和失败。它发动了经济战，拒绝向莫斯科提供可能为其战争机器提供动力的关键商品。美国和英国情报部门甚至将准军事特工派到铁幕后面，希望激起暴力抵抗。最后一个倡议最终被放弃了，因为它产生了太多的挑衅，但收益太少。但穿越危险地带意味着想方设法让敌人处于守势。39

To that end, the United States initially offered Marshall Plan aid to Eastern Europe as well as Western Europe—the calculation being that a hyper-suspicious Moscow would force the satellite states to decline and thereby destroy its own moral authority in the bloc. Washington subsequently beamed radio broadcasts into Eastern Europe to play up the crimes and failings of the Soviet-backed regimes. It waged economic warfare, denying Moscow critical goods that might feed its war machine. The U.S. and UK intelligence services even dropped paramilitary operatives behind the Iron Curtain in hopes of stirring up violent resistance. The last initiative was eventually ditched because it produced too much provocation at too little benefit. But traversing the danger zone meant finding ways of putting the enemy on the defensive.39

具有讽刺意味的是，在一场失败的赌博之后，美国人的冒险行为变得最为明显。在 20 世纪 40 年代后期，杜鲁门将军费开支控制在远低于他的军事首脑认为谨慎的水平。但莫斯科在 1949 年研制出原子弹的成功改变了这种计算。一份名为 NSC-68 的高度机密报告于 1950 年 4 月得出结论，美国可能会在 1954 年面临“最危险的一年”。两个月后，当朝鲜军队在斯大林的支持下入侵韩国时，杜鲁门总结道共产党人将“现在使用武装入侵和战争”来征服他们的敌人。40

American risk-taking became most pronounced, ironically, after a gamble that went awry. During the late 1940s, Truman had kept military expenditures far below what his military chiefs deemed prudent. But Moscow’s success in developing the A-bomb in 1949 shifted that calculus. The United States, a highly classified report known as NSC-68 concluded in April 1950, might face a “year of maximum danger” as soon as 1954. When North Korean forces, with Stalin’s blessing, invaded South Korea two months later, Truman concluded that the Communists would “now use armed invasion and war” to subjugate their enemies.40

美军以沉重的代价挫败了朝鲜在半岛的进攻。9 月，道格拉斯·麦克阿瑟将军在朝鲜后方进行了出色的两栖登陆，扭转了局势。杜鲁门随后允许麦克阿瑟向北奔向鸭绿江，希望他能够在不激怒中国或苏联干预的情况下重新统一整个朝鲜。赌注没有兑现：1950 年末，毛泽东的军队在靠近中国边境的地方突袭了过度扩张的美国军队，造成了美国历史上最严重的军事失败之一，并为一场新的全球战争蒙上了阴影。如果这样的冲突爆发，参谋长联席会议主席奥马尔布拉德利将军警告说，“我们可能有失败的危险。” 41正如 NSC-68 所说，现在很明显，美国必须紧急关闭已经敞开的脆弱窗口。

U.S. forces blunted, at heavy cost, North Korea’s drive down the peninsula. In September, General Douglas MacArthur turned the tide with a brilliant amphibious landing behind North Korean lines. Truman then allowed MacArthur to race north toward the Yalu River, hoping that he could reunify all of Korea without provoking Chinese or Soviet intervention. The wager did not pay: In late 1950, Mao’s forces jumped overextended American units near the Chinese border, inflicting one of the worst military defeats in U.S. history and casting the shadow of a new global war. If such a conflict erupted, warned General Omar Bradley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, “we might be in danger of losing.” 41 It was now clear, as NSC-68 had argued, that America must urgently close the window of vulnerability that had opened wide.

从 1950 年开始，美国将在进行大规模军事集结和全球外交攻势的同时，满足于在朝鲜进行激烈的平局。五角大楼的支出几乎翻了两番，美国的原子武库大约翻了三番，美国常规部队的规模翻了一番多。42华盛顿与日本、澳大利亚、新西兰和菲律宾结成军事同盟。它向欧洲派遣了更多的军队和飞机，并指派德怀特艾森豪威尔将军将联盟打造成一支真正的战斗力量。杜鲁门和艾奇逊甚至将十年前入侵和蹂躏苏联的西德纳入北约，并开始准备重建其军队。所有这些措施都会激怒苏联。但正如艾奇逊所说，“唯一比实施该计划更危险的事情就是不实施它。” 43

From 1950 onward, the United States would settle for a ferocious draw in Korea while undertaking a massive military buildup and a worldwide diplomatic offensive. Pentagon spending nearly quadrupled, the American atomic arsenal roughly tripled, and the size of U.S. conventional forces more than doubled.42 Washington sealed military alliances with Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and the Philippines. It sent more troops and planes to Europe and assigned General Dwight Eisenhower to whip the alliance into a real fighting force. Truman and Acheson even brought West Germany—the country that had invaded and savaged the Soviet Union a decade before—into NATO and began preparing to rebuild its military. All of these measures would anger the Soviet Union. But as Acheson put it, “the only thing that was more dangerous than undertaking this program was not undertaking it.” 43
